item.description:
#article #date
tags: #article
#date 19.10.2021
related: Is the Heat Wave Caused By Climate Change? This Is What Scientists Say
source: ‘Case closed’: 99.9% of scientists agree climate emergency caused by humans

It is really case closed. There is nobody of significance in the scientific community who doubts human-caused climate change
- lead author, Mark Lynas, a visiting fellow at Cornell University
Many senior Republicans continue to cast doubt on the link between human activity and the climate crisis as market researchers have advised them to do since at least the presidency of George W Bush. According to the Center for American Progress, 30 US senators and 109 representatives “refuse to acknowledge the scientific evidence of human-caused climate change”. Several big media organisations and social networks also promote climate-sceptical views that have little or no basis in science.

item.title: More than 90% of rainforest carbon offsets by biggest certifier are worthless
item.description:
#article #climate #carbonoffsetting #year
tags: #article #climate #carbonoffsetting
#year 2023
related:
source: Revealed: more than 90% of rainforest carbon offsets by biggest certifier are worthless, analysis shows

Investigation into Verra carbon standard finds most are ‘phantom credits’ and may worsen global heating.

at least 90% of Verra’s rainforest Redd+ carbon credits do not represent real emission reductions: instead of 94.4m just 5.5m missions are actually reduced
project baselines are now re-assessed every six years rather than ten.
Verra strongy disagrees with the foundings
The challenge isn’t around measuring carbon stocks; it’s about reliably forecasting the future, what would have happened in the absence of the Redd+ activity.
multiple companies have now moved away from using Verra credits or are looking closer into the projects
- e.g. supporting now research for net-zero technology The implications of this analysis are huge. Companies are using credits to make claims of reducing emissions when most of these credits don’t represent emissions reductions at all.
Rainforest protection credits are the most common type on the market at the moment. And it’s exploding, so these findings really matter. But these problems are not just limited to this credit type. These problems exist with nearly every kind of credit.
One strategy to improve the market is to show what the problems are and really force the registries to tighten up their rules so that the market could be trusted. But I’m starting to give up on that. I started studying carbon offsets 20 years ago studying problems with protocols and programs. Here I am, 20 years later having the same conversation. We need an alternative process. The offset market is broken.
- Barbara Haya, director of the Berkeley Carbon Trading Project, researching carbon credits for 20 years


Only a handful of Verra’s rainforest projects showed evidence of deforestation reductions, according to two studies, with further analysis indicating that 94% of the credits had no benefit to the climate.
The threat to forests had been overstated by about 400% on average for Verra projects, according to analysis of a 2022 University of Cambridge study.
Gucci, Salesforce, BHP, Shell, easyJet, Leon and the band Pearl Jam were among dozens of companies and organisations that have bought rainforest offsets approved by Verra for environmental claims.
Human rights issues are a serious concern in at least one of the offsetting projects. The Guardian visited a flagship project in Peru, and was shown videos that residents said showed their homes being cut down with chainsaws and ropes by park guards and police. They spoke of forced evictions and tensions with park authorities.
item.guid: media/articles/More than 90% of rainforest carbon offsets by biggest certifier are worthless.md

item.description:

So you see what others thinking and are not focused on yourself!

Denying requests opens up your time/resources to say yes to the right opportunities.
Built your (little) world to say yes to the right things.


If you don't have time for something, at least let the other person know it.
e.g.
Unfortunately, at the moment I don't have time to help you with this project.
I hope you find someone else to support you.

E.g. with
Thank you for understanding.

Some formulations you want to use to be kind & polite:

Thank you for thinking of me.
Sounds like a great project/event/idea, but this is not for us.
I don't have enough time on my plate to offer you quality help.
"Sadly" or "unfortunately"

item.title: Atomic habits
item.description:
Noticing
plan exacetly when you do what
plan for failure (failure premortem)
think about why you failed your most important goal in 6 months
then improve it and make a plan to tackle possible pitfalls
not enough time for the workout on monday at 7pm => do it on Tuesday 6:30am
Wanting
shape your physical environment => make good decisions easy, and bad difficult
make "bad" habits more difficult
in nearly all living rooms, the couches and chairs face the TV, so it is designed to watch TV => instead let the chairs face e.g. a table with a book on it
hide the TV behind something (e.g. set it in the wall behind a "door")
unplug all cables of the TV and just plug them in, when you can say what you want to watch
e.g. don't switch on PC if its quite likely to be just gaming/watching unnecessary videos (not related to the physical environment, but still a good tip ;) )
make "good" habits easier
e.g. putting books in places I see them often
Doing
plan for the start not the finishing line
just start
get repetition
scale habits down to 2 minutes per repetition
reading books => read one page
put on running shoes, step out the door, lock it, go back in
start VSC, open project, read a little bit, shut it down again
=> master the art of showing up (you become the type of person who does it)
=> habit must be established (new normal), before it can be improved
too focues on optimizing, than first establishing habit
right actions leads to the right results anyways
you become somebody through action
e.g. every time you write you are an writer
you stenghten your belief about your identity to be somebody (e.g. being studious when you learn Spanish once a week)
Liking
reward yourself now to be motivated
problem: most good habits have the reward in the future
solutions
hang up a calendar and cross each day you do the habit => now it is about not breaking the chain! blank-calendar-template.png
have 90 red and 10 blue marble
each time you do the habit, you take one marble out
red one => good job, you did your habit
blue one => you do something really fun/cool (e.g. play a game, go out do sports, meet with friends)
surprising and possibly very nice experience


little moments decide over a lot of time
e.g. if I start Windows I am going to game
but if I start Ubuntu, I am much more likely to be productive
that also means, that we don't have to change a lot, to be much more the person we want to become
can be helped (to get the right entry points) through properly arranging environment, doing it with others, ...
join a group where your wanted behaviour is the normal behaviour

Use habits to your advantage. Build positive ones to get the most out of every day.

Habit is either the best of all servants or the worst of all bosses.
- Nathaniel Emmens

Habits are important and very strong.


That the theory according to Foggs

Motivation: Why do you want to change it or stop with something? You need a strong reason, otherwise it won't work.
Ability: Do you have the time, money, resources to do it?
Trigger: How you change it and with what it is replaced.

Replace a bad habit, the time or what you do, with a good one.

item.title: How habits work
item.description:
It's a cycle of trigger, craving, reaction and award.


First there is a situation to change/solve e.g. a dark room.

You want to see something, so you want to light the room.

You react accordingly to get what you want by switching on the light.

In the end you get the reward for your routine: You see something!

item.title: Notes taking
item.description:
Take notes and create notes by asking yourself questions about the usefulness of the taken notes and how you can connect this new thing to other learned things. Create and use to remember it.



Think: Even before you have to take notes, e.g. before a lecture or a book, be clear what you want to get out, what is your aim with the notes later.
Identify: During the notes taking process, find out what is (most) helpful for you aim.
Prioritise: After go over your notes again and highlight the most important things or summarise them.

Why do you take notes? That is an important questions because the answer determines also the approach. In most cases we want to remember the information for a long time. But it is also very likely that we won't remember everything just after gaining the information for the first time and taking notes. So we also have to take notes in a way that we can later review them and learn or better remember more of it.
So we take notes to group and connect the new information in a way we understand them better. And to have a fundament for further learning.

Divide e.g. your sheet into two columns. On the one side just take notes. On the other side get creative and create notes yourself connected to your taken notes.

Best practice is to group notes by subject. If there are sub-subjects just indent.
Don't transcript what you e.g. hear. That is not efficient for remembering or using them later. Prioritise.

Learning a complex but high efficient abbreviations system could take too long and would be another challenge. By creating your own ones, you can always adapt what you abbreviate and create them on your own.
For a topic where a long word e.g. artificial intelligent => AI is used often you can make your own abbreviation and just put a post it (or write it down at the beginning or end of this section) with the abbreviation on your notes to remember what it meant later on.

In the create notes column, you should deepen the learned things.
Not limited but standard questions for creating notes can be:

How can I use this?
Why must I use this?
When will I use this?

It is better to not take (too much) notes while listening or reading. You don't and should not write everything down, but just enough to remember when it is a presentation, or even pause the video/audiobook or close the book before taking notes.
That way you really focus on the information input first and are not disctracted by note taking. Afterwards you do active recalling and your brain has to review/remember it again. This is especially important for getting it to the long term memory.

After the e.g. lecture or section of book review your notes, because the memory of it is still fresh and maybe you want to add or change some things.

Even take and create notes on fictional topics to keep you practice this skill and test your comprehenions on reading/listening/...

There are two main approaches:

By hand you can take notes more freely and e.g. draw things.
By typing (e.g. on a laptop) you are (probably) faster and write nicer.
Today we have the opportunity to have the best of two worlds with a tablet.

item.title: Learn the most used words first
item.description:
#language #learning #frequency #video
tags: #language #learning #frequency
overview: Language Learning
related:
sources: #video The fastest way to learn a new language: The solar system theory

Learn the most frequently used words in a language first. That way you boost how much you learn tremendiously because you also use it the most (in this language).


To get going, the best way is to learn the most frequent words (and word compositions) first. That way your learning curve is far steeper and you have more motivation to go on.
The specific 10% or 20% of words you use the most not just differ from language to language but also from person to person with different interest. That doesn't mean you should spend hours on figuring out what words you use the often.
But the really most used words e.g. "and" or "the" in English you should learn first. For nearly any language there are already some lists, apps or websites that can help with that.

And it is also just more efficient. Like always the 80/20 rule also applies here.

How to know what and when to buy? There are different options to estimate the value and the "future" of a share:

With numbers e.g. P/I (If a company really makes profit and is worth what a share costs)

#video How to Excel at Math and Science about the #book "A Mind for Number - How to excel at Math and Science"


Focus mode: focusing on one task/problem
Diffuse mode: coming up with different solutions (in the background)


if one already has a solution, it is much more difficult to find a better one/think of other solutions


first focus on a thing (e.g. learging)
if one is stuck, take a break and "distract yourself" (e.g. sports, sleep, shower, walk) --> brain is working on the problem in the background and you may find the solution quicker
for that to work, you have to know the basics of the problem (if you don't understand it at all, you most likely won't understand it later either...)


learning every day a little bit (you cannot either gain muscles in a week)
recalling is the best way
read and then think/recall it (e.g. closing the book you've just read)



attempting problem
reading solution
"Oh I now know it" --> one doesn't :(


understand basics: ask (friend, teacher), read about it
attempt problem and work it completely through
solution was needed: work problem through again and not only know what to do but also WHY, to make it work on different problems too and make new brain connections
solution was not needed: perfect, congratulation, go on to next problem
after a time (solving problems, at least one) take a break (--> get into diffuse mode, to let brain process the new thoughts)
practice lots of problems


go on, if you have successfully solved a problem without the solution (of couse best to do 1-2, but maybe, as the recalling technique, make another related problem later)
mix up problems (e.g. don't just do some of a section, because in the test, they won't be divided into sections either)


do the difficult/unwanted task right in the morning or/and after coming home (e.g. from school) to keep up/have the momentum


know (e.g. write down, hang on an image/material) why you do it
picture oneself after the done work


take your time to really understand e.g. the problem and how to apply it instead of just solving it, maybe even with the solution


setting timer also simulates a time pressure (as in an exam)


patient persistance is very important (learning curve is not linear) --> gets more fun, if you get better ;)
learn how to learn with the techniques above
mindset (shift) can help/is quite important

item.title: Speed reading
item.description:
Is about the ability to read and understand text really fast.
It is an ability you can learn and train which has a lot of upside to other areas.


According to Michel Wozniak because in speed reading you can flexibly alter your speed. So it is not just going always faster, but controlling the pace: Have the ability to go quite fast, and still understand a lot, but sometimes slow down to get some tricky sentences, too.

Unlearn bad habits/techniques you learned in primary school

Regression: Jump back to parts of the text you already read
Subvocalize:
Get slower to understand more


Less understanding: When reading faster, your brain has more input and cannot wander away as easily as when reading slow. So you don't lose focus.
More difficult/stressful: You already have more practice (speed reading needs practice!) and you are faster finished with a given text.
Not valued: Because your control the pace, you can go faster on difficult/important passages.


Practice a lot: It needs a lot of practice to improve.
Stop subvocalizing: Stop with speaking or moving your physical vocal parts while reading (Just around 120 wpm). Mental subvocalizing can be helpful for understanding, but it also slows you down.
Solution: For vocal parts just take something in your mouth while speaking. For mentally subvocalizing you can count (e.g. one, two, three, one, ...), which can be distracting, or tab with your fingers. Tabbing with finger has the downside, that you "lose" one hand (so you cannot hold the book and use the other hand to guide your eyes anymore).
Guide the eyes: Guiding the eyes with e.g. your finger or a pen is crucial.
It helps with not jumping back (your eyes want to stay on the moving object), holding the pace and controlling where the eyes start/end on a line.
Group the words: Some words like "the world" can be comprehended as one thing instead of reading two words.
This can be practised by grouping words in a book before reading and then trying to read a unit or rather take a unit in as one.
Read in the middle: Try to read the first and last word without focusing on it.
You can exercise it with drawing lines and guiding the focus of your eyes.
Abkürzungen:

wpm = words per minute

item.description:

overview: if it is a subtopic to a broader topic like a summary note of notes

sources: Neuroscientist: "This Simple Exercise Will Improve Your Eye Vision" | Andrew Huberman

Habits to improve eye sight or at least strengthen it.


A lot of the times we look at (little) screens not far away like the smartphone or laptop. Eye muscles have to tighten up to focus something close to us.

We should go outside and look at the horizon (not focusing on anything specific) for 20-30 minutes every 90 minutes. Every 30 minutes take a break and relax the eye (muscles).

relax eyes every 30 minutes
every 90 minutes take a longer break (preferrable going outside and looing at the landscape around)

Then make smooth pursuit exercises where you move an object e.g. a pen in front of you in shapes e.g. an eight and follow it with your eyes.
Now move the object back and forth and concentrate again to train different muscles in your eye.

make eye training with an object anywhere you are

item.title: 36 Fragen für ein gutes Gespräch über die Klimakrise
item.description:
#remarkN #remarkN
#remarkN personal goal: Know better questions to ask to talk about climate crisis.
#remarkN Most important takeaway: Maybe not directly talk about climate crisis but rather about what to happened in the past, how to imagine the future and what to change.


Was beschäftigt dich, wenn du an die nächsten 5 Jahre denkst? An die nächsten 30?
Den Begriff «Klimakrise», wie findest du den?
Wo fällt dir auf, dass sich das Wetter und die Natur seit deiner Kindheit verändert haben?
Wie würdest du das Verhältnis von Mensch und Natur beschreiben? Was ist Natur für dich?
Was würdest du sofort ändern, wenn es nicht so schwierig wäre?
Auf welche Frage zum Klima konnte dir noch niemand eine richtig gute Antwort liefern?
Wo siehst du, dass in deiner Stadt oder Gemeinde Massnahmen ergriffen werden?
Was geht dir durch den Kopf, wenn du einen SUV siehst?
Hast du Freunde oder Familie, die direkt von Klima­veränderungen betroffen sind?
Es gibt viele Menschen, die sich für eine lebenswerte Zukunft engagieren. Wer inspiriert dich besonders?
Worüber sollte man deiner Meinung nach mehr sprechen?
Kennst du einen guten Witz zur Klimakrise?
Wie hat sich deine Haltung gegenüber der Klima­erwärmung in den vergangenen Jahren verändert? Versuche, so detailliert wie möglich zu erzählen.
Hurra, heute ist dein 100. Geburtstag! Beschreib mal, wie deine Nachbarschaft und die Welt dann aussehen.
Wie hat das, was du beruflich machst, einen Einfluss auf die Welt von morgen?
Was nervt dich an Diskussionen um die Klima­erwärmung?
Stell dir vor, du hättest einen persönlichen «Klima-Coach». Wobei würdest du ihn um Hilfe bitten?
Wen in deinem Umfeld beschäftigt die Klima­erwärmung am meisten? Wieso wohl?
Mit wem hast du das Gefühl, gemeinsam etwas bewirken zu können?
Woran scheitert bislang wirksamer Schutz unserer Lebensgrundlagen?
Was müsste verboten werden?
Was müsste endlich mal erfunden werden?
Wer trägt Verantwortung für eine lebenswerte Zukunft?
Welche Rolle spielt deiner Meinung nach die Wirtschaft in der Klimakrise?
Hast du schon mal einem Kind die Klima­erwärmung erklärt? Wie hat sich das angefühlt?
Was bereitet dir am meisten Sorgen mit Blick auf die Klima­erwärmung? Was macht dich traurig? Wütend?
Wenn man versucht, nachhaltig zu leben, und sich für die Umwelt einsetzt, wie konsequent muss man dann sein?
Worauf bist du stolz?
Was ist mir, deiner Meinung nach, noch zu wenig bewusst?
Was bedeutet «Klima­gerechtigkeit» für dich?
Was ist dir wirklich wichtig im Leben?
Was liegt dir am Herzen, das durch die Klima­erwärmung betroffen ist?
Wozu haben wir sehr unterschiedliche Meinungen? Wie kommt das wohl?
Welche persönliche Erfahrung hat dir Hoffnung gemacht für die Zukunft unseres Planeten?
Was ist die weitreichendste politische Massnahme, die du unterstützen würdest?
Was könnten wir gemeinsam bewegen? Versuchen wir’s?

item.title: A Love Letter to My Brothers
item.description:
#article #patriarchy #remarkN
tags: #article #patriarchy
related:
source: https://medium.com/@MikiKashtan/a-love-letter-to-my-brothers-e2e08d2053e0

Text on patriarchy.

Some people suggest words like "domination system", "culture of dominatin" or "culture of exploitation".
That doesn't work, because they don't work on a material level. Instead patriarchy is connected to "paternity", which is a relationsship that happens on the material, biological plane and isn't an automatic given.

Long period of material dependence on others.
We are entirely dependent on a one-sided giving to be able to survive the first few years of our life, and we continue to be dependent on love for the entirety of our life

Mothering, in this context, means an orientation to others’ needs.

Suggest massive collective trauma from physical and climatic catastrophes as the mechanism of the initial tansitions to patriarchy. So they lost trust in life and turned away from living based on orienting to needs. This leads to a drive of hoarding and accumulating.
Patriarchy became meaningful, when it becomes important who someone's child is in order to pass on to them what has been accumulated.

#remarkN Unclear where to order this section yet
It's clear who is the mother, when a baby is born, but there is no simple way (absend modern DNA reserarch) to know who the father is unless women are controlled. Patriarchy isn't about man, it's about fathering. Patriarchy emerged from turning away from life and aiming to control the processes of life, not women. But controlling women became necessary, to protect the invading group.
After the trauma of an invasion, the women became a threat. They were a link to what came before, to what the incoming invades had lost and came to fear, a symbol of all they couldn't trust any longer. From then on, women's work, experience, wisdom and knowledge, ways of being, need and contributions have been devalued. Example in Europe are times of persecution of women as witches.

Every patriarchal state has pushed outward in an endless cycle of finding new resources — minerals, food, and people — to sustain the practices of the ruling classes and their protectors, the armies and the police, who need to be fed and clothed even while not producing anything on their own.

There is no way to “win” against patriarchy, because against-ness, in itself, is a patriarchal orientation.
I have said, already, that I don’t see us ever fighting patriarchy and winning, nor do I want to win, because then there are, again, losers.

When it comes to patriarchy in particular, all of us enact patriarchal patterns to various degrees.


bring in enough love, to subvert the logic of separation
to eradicate extreme poverty, eradicate extreme wealth
an island of love, an island of commitment to liberation for all, without any exceptions

Poverty is a result and impoverishment the material process that creates it.

It begins with accumulation. This has two consequences: Few having too much while many have too little. Over time leading to a big difference.

From early on, war has had everything to do with women.

In village after village

killed man
incorporated women
to preserve the new male line required controlling the women.

I have always sensed that there must be violence inherent to capitalism, because I couldn’t imagine why, otherwise, the vast number of people whose work lives are one endless, unremitting misery would choose to continue doing this work, day after day.
Capitalism was from the beginning a multi-regional phenomenon in which some people in some regions gain material wealth at the expense of most poeple in the same region and at immense cost to almost all people in other regions (and to all life forms and nature)

which gave Portugal and Spain the authority to take over any land not previously inhabited by or claimed by Christians and to use what's on it and subjugate any people on it.
Still being used today in Canada and US by governments and corporations when encroaching on indigenous populations.

While exploitation and impoverishment existed and continue to exist within Europe, the degree of violence that Europe brought to other places could only be justified by making the target populations less than human. In the beginning because they were not Christians, then because the looked different e.g. darker skin colour. The result of all this is that the vast majority of the world’s poor are dark-skinned.

Also often peasant of the Middle Ages in Europe struggled. But they lived in communites where they could feed and clothe themselves without needing to buy things.
Once forced off the land, they were reduced to making themselves available to work for wages.
The majority of those living below the poverty line in the US are white. Generally people of Eruopean descent, anywhere in the world, have significant material benefits in relation to the groups they have colonized. But there is also a significant number of people of European descent, both in Europe and at least in the English-speaking former colonies, who are seriously not doing well. An Example is the phenomenon "deaths of despair" (drugs, alcohol, suicide) in the ranks of low-earning whites.

First remember all patriarchal societies are male dominated.

No baby is born an oppressor.
There are no exceptions to tenderness, because the exceptions then become the new enemies, and we are then right back to the same cycle.

You have been traumatized, and the result is that, most likely, you act like most men e.g. expect women to get out of your way, remain numb when conftronted by horrors, in groups speak more than women, look at women as secual objects, or not look at them at all if the y don't fit the "perceptual grid".


Learn about what happened to all of us, especially women
I want you to be able to notice, on your own, what is happening, whether you are contributing to it or not, and be able to meet me and the women in your life in holding it. Reach a state where you take initiaitve
make the effor to recover that softness
Ask women to to tell, what they have been trained to keep from men's awareness in the thick web of deception that is constructed to care for your comfort.


250,000 Indian farmers commited suicide due to horrific practices by Monsanto

item.title: Africa may lose $25bn annually to EU carbon border tax
item.description:
#article #date #remarkN #remarkN
tags: #article
#date
related:
source: Africa may lose $25bn annually to EU carbon border tax


EU imposes first carbon border tax in the world from October on (gradually implemented over next 3 years)
prevent companies from producing outside of EU (countries with less restrictions) but still delivering to EU
charge same as domestic production (right now 80 euros/tonne CO2)
initially apply to iron, steel, cement, aluminium, fertilisers, hydrogen and electricity generation
controversial
- study by UN Nations conference on Trade and Development concluded that it represents only a small percentage of global CO₂ emissions ( #remarkN comparing it to global CO2 a lot of things are "controversial" than)
- heavily criticised in the Global South
- protect industry with negative repercussions on regions such as Africa
- because cement, iron and steel, aluminium, fertilisers and electricity are key drivers of the African economy, this policy could reduce the GDP by 0.91% (25 US$ billion at 2021 levels of GDP)
- compared to development cooperation budget from EU to Africa which is just 6.8 US$ billion
- other countries may also introduce such policies
- some people thought about recycling earnings back to production countries, but EU has already committed them to the innovation fund
#remarkN My feeling on it: With this tax, in my understanding, in the current colonial capitalist dependency relationship, the room for manoeuvre of economies in the Global South could already be restricted. But in order to counteract this, it is not the tax that needs to be adjusted, which internalises harmful effects - but there is a need for accompanying measures to eliminate these problems, such as a debt cut:)

The United States is having a long-overdue national reckoning with racism. From criminal justice to pro sports to pop culture, Americans increasingly are recognizing how racist ideas have influenced virtually every sphere of life in this country.


Example: Sierra Club

one of the oldest and largest U.S. conservation organisation
acknowledges racist view of founder John Muir
described Native Americans and Black peopel as dirty, lazy and uncivilized

Example: Theodore Roosevelt

widely revered as first environmental president
was enthusiastic hunter who e.g. the Smithsonian–Roosevelt African Expedition to Kenya in 1909-1910. During this “shooting trip,” Roosevelt and his party killed more than 11,000 animals, including elephants, hippopotamuses and white rhinos.
There is little evidence to support such claims about trophy hunting, which reinforce exploitative models of conservation by removing local communities from lands set aside as hunting reserves.

Example:

Ecologist Aldo Leopold, who is viewed as the father of wildlife management and the U.S. wilderness system
early proponent of the Overpopulation myth
Famed primatologist Jane Goodall also blamed our current environmental challenges in part on overpopulation.

Local communities are often written out of popular narratives on nature conservation.

Many documentaries, such as the 2020 film “Wild Karnataka,” narrated by David Attenborough, entirely ignore local Indigenous people

Many national parks and other land set aside for wilderness conservation are also the ancestral homelands of Native peoples. These communities were forced off their lands during European colonization of North America.

Critics call this strategy “fortress conservation.” According to some estimates, Indigenous and rural communities protect up to 80% of global biodiversity, but receive little benefit in return.
BUT when governments enact socially just nature conservation policies, such as community forestry in Mexico, they are better able to handle conflicts over use of these resources. Socially just nature conservation is possible under two main conditions: Indigenous and rural communities have concrete stakes in protecting those resources and can participate in policy decisions.

item.title: Bildungsniveau wird vererbt, der Traum vom sozialen Aufstieg bleibt hierzulande oft ein Traum
item.description:
#article #education #society #german
tags: #article #education #society
related:
source: https://www.srf.ch/news/schweiz/bildungsniveau-wird-vererbt-der-traum-vom-sozialen-aufstieg-bleibt-hierzulande-oft-ein-traum (srf took it down for some reason)


educational level often gets "inherited" (according to statistics of BFS)
children studying: 27% of educationally disadvantaged families but 70% of parents who studied themselves
Why?
pupils get selected too early (after 6 years)
in comparison: in nearly all other OECD countries, classes are mixed until the ninth or even tenth grade => children with a blockage to learning until 15 years, can be helped better/can be solved more easily
children with academic parents have an easier way in school
often they can (better) help with homework or pay sb. who does this
they can pay more for education (children don't have to earn that fast)
parents have more expectations for their children to study as well
even after a completion apprenticeship ( #german Berufslehre), just 22% make professional baccalaureate and of them just half complete a university of applied sciences and less than one percent study at an university
Unfortunately (don't know why), the article got taken down from srf.ch, so I found it on reddit

Die Schweiz ist punkto soziale Mobilität im internationalen Vergleich nur Mittelmass, zeigen neuste Zahlen des Bundes.
Sepp Blatter, Alt Bundesrat René Felber oder Gewerkschaftsführerin Vania Alleva haben eines gemeinsam: Sie stammen aus einer Arbeiterfamilie, haben studiert und den sozialen Aufstieg geschafft. Solche Aufsteiger und Aufsteigerinnen sind in der Schweiz aber eher die Ausnahme als die Regel.
Das Bildungsniveau wird in der Schweiz meist vererbt, das zeigen die neusten Zahlen des Bundesamts für Statistik (BFS): Nur 27 Prozent der Kinder aus bildungsfernen Familien studieren, bei Kindern mit Akademikereltern sind es 70 Prozent. Warum ist die Schweiz punkto soziale Mobilität im internationalen Vergleich bloss Mittelmass?
Der Traum, von unten nach ganz oben zu gelangen, bleibe in der Schweiz überwiegend ein Traum, sagt Benita Combet, Soziologin an der Universität Zürich. «Die Wahrscheinlichkeit ist sehr gering, dass man vom Tellerwäscher zum Millionär wird.» Wie gross die soziale Mobilität in einer Gesellschaft ist, hänge vor allem davon ab, wie sehr der Staat gewillt sei, diese auch zu unterstützen.
Kinder werden frühzeitig eingespurt
In der Schweiz ist es für Kinder aus bildungsfernen Schichten schwierig, gegenüber den Eltern aufzusteigen. Das liege vor allem daran, dass in der Schule zu früh selektioniert werde: In fast allen Kantonen entscheidet sich nach sechs Jahren Primarschule, in welche Stufe die Schülerinnen und Schüler eingeteilt werden.
In fast allen anderen OECD-Ländern bleiben die Klassen bis in die neunte oder zehnte Klasse leistungsmässig durchmischt. So können Schülerinnen und Schüler, die eine Lernblockade erst mit 15 lösen, einfacher gefördert werden. Das hilft talentierten Kindern, aufzusteigen.
Akademikerkind soll gleichen Weg einschlagen
Aber warum vererben Eltern neben der Haar- und Augenfarbe häufig auch die Berufsziele an ihre Kinder? Combet erklärt: «Kinder mit Eltern mit höherer Bildung haben es einfacher in der Schule. Sei es, weil die Eltern sie in den Hausaufgaben besser unterstützen oder ihnen eine Hausaufgabenhilfe zahlen können.»
Für Akademikerkinder spielen die Kosten einer höheren Bildung auch später kaum eine Rolle, weil sie nicht so rasch Geld verdienen müssen. Ein gewichtiger Faktor sind aber auch die Erwartungen der Akademikereltern an ihre Kinder. «Diesen Eltern ist es häufig wichtig, dass die Kinder einen ähnlichen Bildungsabschluss haben wie sie selbst. Ein krasses Beispiel sind Generationen von Ärztefamilien, wo die Erwartung da ist, dass das Kind den gleichen Weg einschlägt.»
Mehr Allgemeinbildung in der Berufsbildung
Man kann nun natürlich einwenden: Wer sich für eine Berufslehre entscheidet, kann in der Schweiz später dennoch Medizin studieren. Berufsmaturität und Passerelle machen dies möglich. Doch die Hürden sind auf diesem Weg viel höher als für jene, die nach dem Gymnasium direkt an die Uni gehen. Das schreckt viele ab: 22 Prozent mit einem Lehrabschluss machen zwar eine Berufsmatura. Von diesen schliesst dann aber nur etwas mehr als die Hälfte eine Fachhochschule ab. Weniger als ein Prozent studieren an einer Uni.
Das müsse sich ändern, sagt die Soziologin: «Die Schweiz muss sich überlegen, inwieweit sie das Berufsbildungssystem modernisieren will. Sodass mehr Fähigkeiten erlernt werden, die man zwischen verschiedenen Berufen transferieren kann.» Mehr Allgemeinbildung in der Berufsbildung sei dringend notwendig.

item.title: Das hilft gegen Hass im Netz
item.description:
The best antidote is empathy. More under point 3.

With appealing to empathy of the hate speaker, you have the best chance, that they take it down again.
humour and urging words don't (really) work


Addressing: React to a negative post and state hate speech e.g. "What you are writing, is harmful for a lot of people." or "With this statement you are insulting people, who are close to me." Important because
show, that people disagree with this hate speech/opinion
be a model for others and show zivilcourage
saying something is always better, than (just) getting upset
Dislike if possible and you don't have the energy to respond to it
Empathy: Arousing sympathy of the hate speakers.
Not about understanding hate speaker
e.g. "Think about , how you would feel, if ..."
Stimulate change of perspective: Do active counterspeech and try to get hate speakers into the perspective of the victims e.g. "If X (e.g. homosexual) friends of me see this, it makes them sad." or "You for sure also know X humans. What do you think, how they feel, if they see this post?"
Report: Especially for people with a big number of followers e.g. people in politics or/and public. Important
Don't feed the troll i.e. don't give them even more attention.
Argument with facts: Try it, especially if you are an expert in the field, it's about. Unfortunately, it doesn't always work. An alternative is to ask the hate speaker about their facts and sources.
Gather evidence bc. everybody can report racist or homophobic comments (independent of you being affected or not). Make screenshots and contact police.
disclaimer: This doesn't hold for sexist hate speech.
Get help, if you're the one affected by it. And again save all evidence and report to police.
Best is, to let this be done by a friend and also give another person control over the affected accounts e.g. on social media.
try also dedicated/professional help

#article #date

source: Disruptive protest helps rather than hinders activists’ cause, experts say

Results contradict public view that disrupting events such as Wimbledon and Pride achieves nothing

78% of Britains think, disruptive protest hinders activists' causes
But study among experts show a different image
- polled 120 experts in sociology, political science and related disciplines for Social Change Lab, asking "what makes some social movements more successful than others
- believe that strategic disruption is the most important tactical factor for a social movement’s success
- seven in 10 surveyed said movements that have high public awareness and support, such as climate crisis organisations, could enjoy its fruits
- only 30% thought disruptive tactics were effective for issues with high awareness but low support, such as anti-vaccination
- other important factors
- mobilise and scale quickly in response to external events
- least important
- decentralised decision making
- greatest internal threats
- internal conflict or movement infighting
- lack of clear political objectives Whether we like it or not, the history of social change is also a history of political contestation and disruption. Disruption of everyday life is often the best way to receive media attention, generate visibility for a cause and above all to push political and economic elites to compromise and accept change, if only to protect their own interests.
- Prof Bart Cammaerts, professor of politics and communication at the London School of Economics

item.title: Earth’s inner core may be reversing its rotation
item.description:
#article #science #earth
tags: #article #science #earth
related:
source: https://www.sciencenews.org/article/earth-inner-core-reverse-rotation

Earth’s inner core may have temporarily stopped rotating relative to the mantle and surface, researchers report in the January 23 Nature Geoscience. Now, the direction of the inner core’s rotation may be reversing — part of what could be a roughly 70-year-long cycle that may influence the length of Earth’s days and its magnetic field — though some researchers are skeptical.
Song and Yang infer that the inner core may oscillate with a roughly 70-year periodicity — switching directions every 35 years or so. Because the inner core is gravitationally linked to the mantle and magnetically linked to the outer core, the researchers say these oscillations could explain known 60- to 70-year variations in the length of Earth’s days and the behavior of the planet’s magnetic field. However, more work is needed to pin down what mechanisms might be responsible.

In 2022, he and a colleague reported that seismic waves from nuclear tests show the inner core may reverse its rotation every three years or so. Meanwhile, other researchers have proposed that the inner core isn’t moving at all. Instead, they say, changes to the shape of the inner core’s surface could explain the differences in wave travel times.

Future observations will probably help disentangle the discrepancies between these studies, Vidale says. For now, he’s unruffled by the purported chthonic standstill. “In all likelihood, it’s irrelevant to life on the surface, but we don’t actually know what’s happening,” he says. “It’s incumbent on us to figure it out.”
item.guid: media/articles/Earth’s inner core may be reversing its rotation.md

item.description:

related:
source: Europe’s climate movement is fractured and stuck — here is a way forward



right-wing politicians/groups/governments
repression with surveillance and pre-emptive arrests, dangerous rhetoric
movement has to contend with the appeal of stability, security and continuity presented by the governing political forces during multiple crisis like war, COVID, ....


Movements led by those who are most affected by an issue are strongest.
We need to ask
who is the climate movement
what are the issues it deals with
how it embraces those new frontlines
in what way its different parts relate to each other
This is not a calling out, it’s a calling in — into a different movement.

This outline is less of a blueprint and more of a map of exploration

A broad, unbranded, alliance of sectoral organisations that regularly and visibly disrupt public life
small number of leaders of large membership organisation
so not just one organisation can be blamed
Light coordination group with key people to bring
global analysis
connections to link different movements/organisations together
European school of climate disobedience for mass trainings
digital-savvy onboarding clearinghouse for a basic "movement kit" and to distribute people where they best fit
Organised frontlines and strong connections of trust between them and NGOs
A deep and properly resourced organising and leadership development operation

Also need to reflect on different part

where to use our strengths
where to question our weaknesses
When (in the year) do we need what actions?
reimagine our identification as activists to the broader base in Europe


make movement more resilient: cannot afford further setbacks just bc. of other "crisis"
new climate movement e.g. not just "staying below 1.5°C" or "keep fossil in the ground" but all of it We need to be all of those and also build a climate movement that connects across energy poverty, climate impacts, dignity for migrant lives and trans people. A movement that takes action in Europe in recognition and reparation of the historical debt and wound we’ve inflicted to the Global South, and the wounds we’re inflicting to our geographically nearest communities. That climate movement is much more diverse and cross-issue, grounded in people’s daily lives, full of hope and vision, with new frontiers and frontlines who take its lead.
- Nicolò Wojewoda is the Europe Regional Director at 350.org, based in Ireland

item.title: Hört auf mit dem Klimawandel
item.description:
(Summary by private-ai)

The text discusses the prevalence and impact of the term "climate change" in today's society. It highlights how the term has become an omnipresent entity in media and public discourse, often attributed as the cause for various natural disasters and crises worldwide. Politicians frequently talk about fighting and addressing climate change as one of humanity's greatest challenges. However, the text questions who or what exactly is this powerful force known as climate change. It traces the origin of the term "climate change" back to the Framework Convention on Climate Change of the UN in 1992, which defined it as a change in climate attributed to human activity. The text also mentions the role of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) in documenting the complex effects of human-made greenhouse gases on the climate system and identifying the responsible parties, including the fossil fuel industry, banks, governments, and beneficiaries of the fossil fuel status quo. It points out that the media and politicians have simplified and merged these complex causal chains under the term "climate change," while the original term "greenhouse effect" has faded. The text suggests that this framing was influenced by oil companies, who earlier presented the issue as purely scientific, without acknowledging their own role in the problem. Ultimately, the term "climate change" has captured the public's attention, with some perceiving it as an impending catastrophe, while others see it as a slow and gradual global climate transformation.
With the fact that the climate is "changing" without attributing the cause of this change to deliberate contamination of the atmosphere by greenhouse gases. This strategy aims to divert attention from the responsible parties and downplay their culpability.
The political scientist Mario Candeias predicts a future dominated by a hegemonic "Green Capitalism" that will lead to new confrontations between the West and the Global South amidst a world plagued by violence and disasters resulting from climate extremes. Candeias advocates for a democratic and solidarity-based way of life, with a socialist perspective, as a guideline for a post-growth era. He calls for disruptive strategies within the Left to break away from the existing political framework.
One way to initiate this rupture is through a different use of language, including the conscious choice of words. The term "climate change" should be replaced with more explicit language that identifies the problem as the deliberate contamination of the atmosphere by profit-driven corporations. The Guardian newspaper has already begun using terms such as "human made climate change" or "climate crisis as the result of burning fossil fuels" to reframe the discourse and empower the speakers to take action.


"Climate change" has become an all-encompassing term in media and public discourse.
It is often attributed as the cause for natural disasters and crises worldwide.
Politicians talk about fighting and addressing climate change as a major challenge.
The term originated from the UN's Framework Convention on Climate Change.
The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has provided scientific evidence about the complex effects of human-made greenhouse gases on the climate system.
The fossil fuel industry, banks, governments, and beneficiaries of the fossil fuel status quo are identified as responsible parties.
The media and politicians have simplified and merged complex causal chains under the term "climate change."
The original term "greenhouse effect" has faded.
Oil companies, presenting the issue as mainly scientific, influenced this framing.
The term "climate change" is perceived by some as an imminent catastrophe, while others view it as a gradual transformation of the global climate.
Language plays a crucial role in public discourse on climate change.
The choice of words significantly affects people's perception of the crisis.
The term "climate change" obscures the cause and effect of the problem, leading to depoliticization.
Different actors manipulate the definitions provided by scientific institutions for their own interests.
A conscious shift in language is needed to address the problem adequately.

item.title: IPCC climate reports reveal an unequal science
item.description:
#article #date
tags: #article
#date
related: IPCC Reports Overview
source: IPCC’s climate reports reveal an unequal science


The IPCC has published a Synthesis Report (AR6 SYR) that highlights the urgency of reducing emissions to avoid the worst impacts of climate change.
However, concerns have been raised about the feasibility of the models used to chart decarbonisation pathways.
Research has shown that projections maintain current developmental inequities and perpetuate colonial inequalities.


The models used to chart decarbonisation pathways may not reflect or preserve the principles of equity and rights to development while charting decarbonisation pathways.
Coal is singled out for rapid and drastic declines in the models, jeopardising socio-political feasibility.
A lack of consideration is given to the burden of energy transition on poorer countries while assuming all capital required is available.


Projections for near-term emissions reductions are more feasible for developed countries, leading to limited energy consumption for developing countries from overall sources of renewables and goods and services which restrict development.


Research has shown that projections maintain current developmental inequities and perpetuate colonial inequalities.
Projections maintain the Global North’s energy privilege at a per capita level 2-3 times higher than in developing nations and assume the perpetuation of existing inequities for decades to come.
Criticisms also focus on bioenergy with carbon capture, which could appropriate land in the developing world to support the Global North’s energy privilege resulting in devastating consequences like on food systems, water, and biodiversity.


Climate models need to better reflect real-world difficulties and consider factors like distributive justice.
The models must ease ambiguities in intergovernmental negotiations needed to combat climate change without sacrificing policy guidance.

Obwohl die Schweiz mit ihrer fortschrittlichen Wirtschaft im Inland <0.1% der globalen Emissionen verursacht, spielt sie als internationales Wirtschafts- und Finanzzentrum eine bedeutende Rolle in der Dekarbonisierung. Wir schätzen, dass die Schweiz durch hier ansässige internationale Unternehmen mittels direkt kontrollierte und importbedingte Emissionen einen Einfluss auf das 7- bis 10-fache der Inlandemissionen hat, bzw. noch deutlich mehr, wenn man den gesamten Einflussbereich inklusive Wertschöpfungsketten berücksichtigt. Für Emissionen im Zusammenhang mit Finanzflüssen aus der Schweiz kommt nochmal ein 14- bis 18-Faches dazu beziehungsweise noch mehr, wenn man weitere Aktivitäten wie zum Beispiel Investitionen in Staatsanleihen mitberücksichtigt. Es gilt daher, die Schweizer Wirtschaft bestmöglich zu unterstützen, ihr Dekarbonisierungspotential auszuschöpfen.

item.title: On Stewarding Love & Liberation
item.description:
#article #date #remarkN #DebtForClimate #remarkN #remarkN
tags: #article
#date
related:
source: On Stewarding Love & Liberation

writer: Panthea Lee

Yet if the last 15 years have taught me anything, it is that global capitalists and white saviours are all too happy to treat disasters as anomalies. And from a place of convenient amnesia, they continue to sacrifice our most vulnerable.

build a good foundation
e.g. when founding a helping organisation what legal entity fits the best?
take care of oneself: it's a marathon not a sprint
not more data about granular activities is needed, but remaking overall structure
individual level: provide money to those in need (they don't need your ideas)
global level: debt relief bc. Poor nations pay highest debt service in 20 years -campaigners ( #remarkN #DebtForClimate )
The development programs that are most precisely and easily measured are the least transformational, and those programs that are most transformational are the least measurable.
- Andrew Natsios, former administrator of the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) in [The Clash of the Counter-bureaucracy](https://www.cgdev.org/publication/clash-counter-bureaucracy-and-development
For truest things in life are also the least measurable: Harmony and balance is the natural state of the universe to which we must return. Your suffering is my suffering, your liberation is my liberation. Love is the only force that can drive lasting, structural change.
- author

we need different approaches and unite behind a common goal ( #remarkN maybe that also applies for me: I shouldn't bother too much with what is the best strategy and which organisations fits best, but rather bring in my skills and do the best I can wherever this is)
ranking them and just doing the "best" isn't helpful
staying small is maybe a privilege (even if it's tempting)
one (better) idea: invest in many groups in many places doing what works in their space and time ( #remarkN politics of many streams instead of mainstream (found nearly same phrase in a question in this article. I think it's very nice!))
lasting change comes from embodied conviction that we are all one and our struggles and (thus) our freedom are connected
detach from collective suffering is an illusion
individual healing cannot happen without collective healing
trauma is not the story of what happened a long time ago but a residue that's living inside of us now
to heal, first remember and tell about past horrific events and ongoing structural harm but keep in mind that there is not a singular truth and memory
no amount of reform (e.g. including "green" investment) within the existing operating system can change the structure of the current system
capitalism actively creates inequality and poverty
According to the Transition Resource Circle, for every dollar of new economic growth, 93 cents ends up in the hands of the 1% — and 5 cents in the hands of the world’s majority, or 60% of humanity.
**We don’t need better ideas — we need better relationships.
(e.g. important for a facilitator) How to bring out each individual’s brilliance and weave them into shared magic?

Despite claiming to reduce CO2 emissions, VW's private jet flights have significantly increased.
The company has a fleet of eight top-of-the-line jets, half of which are long-range.
VW benefits from exceptions to energy taxes and emission trading.
VW can operate its own jets as a charter and avoid energy taxes.
Julia Jirmann from the Network for Tax Justice criticizes VW for renting its own jets and saving taxes.
The state may be losing millions of euros annually by allowing VW to avoid these taxes.
The emissions from VW's private jets are estimated to be equivalent to those of around 6,000 people in Germany annually.
VW's sustainability reports do not disclose emissions data for private jet flights.
Some private jets may have been used for personal reasons, not company use.
Flights to tourist destinations are usually not for business travel, but this information is not available for those booked by others or by employees.
The company claims to be reducing emissions and has sold two of its private jets, but has not included emissions data for private jets in its sustainability reports.

item.title: Reimagining Solidarity
item.description:
#article #solidarity #culture #growth #date #remarkN #remarkN #remarkN #remarkN
tags: #article #solidarity #culture #growth
#date 24.08.2023
related:
source: Reimagining Solidarity


whenever doing media, we ask ourselves "How can people see themselves in this story?" #remarkN very important to include and try to get people connected to a story
Solidarity is
- fluid
- weaves communities together with every act of compassion e.g.
- listen deeply without judgment or interruption
- be generous without expecting praise or recognition #remarkN no expectations is quite helpful in everyday life to be a more happy/positive and helping person :)
- recognition of our shared humanity
- act on the same level without power or control over the needs of others
Solidarity is NOT
helping others for applause, profit or privileges e.g.
industry/billionaire/state claiming to have solution for liberation
philanthropist donating to another billionaire's foundation
oil company investing in carbon credits for a sustainability report
(political) leaders flying to summits on climate change
"cruelty-free" brand busting their employees' unions
conserving land by making national parks and displacing indigenous people
stranger claiming to support your struggle while comparing your dignified rage to the violence of your oppressor
Minga (from the Quechua language (Mink'a)): "reciprocal system of community work"
it is a call to action towards a common good that starts from the fundamental need, and joy, to come together to care for the community one's part of, whether or not there is an issue to be solved.
in contrast todays solidarity
arises from the awareness of sb. else's need ( #remarkN in my opinion right now, doing good is always helping (others), so this isn't bad)
act to seek good in order to counteract evil
less for the sake of doing good
with Capitalism came the idea of "not doing anything for free"
individualistic mindset
#remarkN I don't think, it was easier earlier in history to get something for free, but maybe in family. But there were also a lot of norms. At least in some parts of the world, the state has somehow of a safety net. But unfortunately, people have less safety from their communities or/and families (if there even is sth. like that around)
Solidarity does not exist in a vacuum
solidarity is part of a system of values that help nurture and strengthen e.g. compassion, respect, commitment.
Without that system: nothing but a performative act of giving.
often believed that being in solidarity means giving up something e.g. money, time, labour.
but it is rather reciprocal, joyful, bountiful.
But long-lasting transformation comes from the “we” — from the will to build instead of the fear of losing.

Within the European Union, Germany plays a key role in the energy transition. However, its main electricity producer, RWE, is one of Europe’s largest coal plant operators and CO2 emitters, and Europe’s largest lignite producer. In 2021, coal still accounted for 33% of its electricity production, and RWE plans to continue running its largest lignite-fired power stations in Germany until 2038. It’s therefore no surprise that many financial institutions have excluded RWE from their financial services following their adoption of a robust coal exit policy. But many investors remain invested in RWE and keep fueling the company’s threatening strategy despite having taken strong climate pledges. item.title: The huge climate impact of the middle classes
item.description:
#disclaimerN



world’s richest 10%, most of the middle classes in developed countries ( anyone paid more than about $40,000 (£32,000) a year) => responsible for half of all global emissions
#disclaimerN So probably all of Swiss people


beginning (1990s, start of climate negotiations) most inequality in carbon emissions where between nations => three decades later, most inequality is between rich and poor within countries
“It’s very important to stress that big gaps between countries still remain. But on top of this you now also have a lot of within-country inequality"

e.g. IEA data shows that the poorest 10% in the US still have a footprint bigger than 90% of those in India.
in all cases: richest 10% cause as much as poorest 50%
USA/China: even more than poorest 70%
Central Africa: even as much as remaining 90%
key factors/differences are
transportation: 20-40x higher than poorest 10%
USA/Canada: 1/3 of emissions of richest 10% caused through traffic and as much as poorest 70%
consumption: 20-50x higher
If you just focus on the average, you’re missing a big part of the problem and you might also miss the right policy"
- said Dr Lucas Chancel, a co-director of the World Inequality Lab at the Paris School of Economics, whose team have tracked the rise of carbon inequality within countries.
Thus carbon emission taxes can be

useless e.g. when people have to pay more, but they really need cars bc. they live in rural places
or even backfire e.g. "gilets jaunes"
It will not be enough to just impose taxes on carbon, as the rich can essentially afford to pay the extra amount, while poor people would be more affected.


policy sticks e.g. taxation only on those, who have capacity for it
policy carrots e.g. subsidies for those who are unfairly burned by rising fuel and food prices


amount of millionaires likely to grow from 51 million (2021) to 511 million (2050) (taking inflation into account) => that alone could wipe the remaining carbon budget of 250bn tonnes

a recent report, noted that a “relatively modest” progressive wealth tax of 1.5% on people with $100m or more in assets – 0.001% of the global population – would raise $295bn a year. That is a similar amount to what is needed to protect the world’s people from the growing impacts of the climate crisis.

Rich lifestyles can change to reduce emissions without damaging wellbeing. What matters most to people is our relationships with others and our ability to be social, and those things aren’t carbon intensive to enjoy or maintain.

is that gender is determined by genitalia, but intersex children and those with a misalignment between gender identity and biological sex prove otherwise.Gender identity is a personal and unique aspect of an individual that is not determined by their genitals.

Climate change is causing water scarcity in some Alpine regions of Switzerland.
The summers in Switzerland in the last 30 years have tended to become increasingly drier, leading to less snow and glacier melting in the spring and summer.
The water scarcity is causing concerns for traditional alpine farming.
Cattle are facing water scarcity, as a cow can drink up to 100 litres of water on a hot day.
Helicopter companies have been flown in to conduct water deliveries to particularly dry Alpine regions.
Millions of francs have been invested in water supply projects to ensure that dry Alpine pastures can continue to be cultivated.
The number of approved projects rose from 10 ten years ago to 40 last year costing $22mn financed by federal, cantonal and local resources, as well as owners.
Around a third of Swiss agricultural surface is under stress due to the water scarcity.

item.title: We Should Celebrate the World’s Population Passing the Eight Billion Mark
item.description:
#article #capitalism #economy #climatechange #remarkN
tags: #article #capitalism #economy #climatechange
related:
source: https://jacobin.com/2022/11/world-population-growth-malthusianism-ecosocialism/

Sections of the environmental movement bemoaned the birth of the world’s eight-billionth person, but the Left should have no part in this cynical misanthropy. The cause of food insecurity and climate change is the irrationality of capitalism — not rising populations.

Between 10'000 BC and 1700 with just reaching 600 million (around 1700) life expactency was less than thirty years.
Now with a world's population of over 8 billion people, it's at 73 years.

Malthusians less willing to blame all humans have argued that the problem is not all people, just a subset of wealthy individuals ( #remarkN Malthusianism is the idea of population growth is potentially exponential while the growth of the food supply or other resources is linear, which eventually reduces living standard to the point of triggering a population die off.) Argument of them is, that all would live by the standards of Americans, we would need 4 planet Earths.

In previous systems, famines were caused by bad harvests and natural scarcity; under capitalism they are caused by the fact that people lack the money to afford to eat.
The simple fact is that inequality and poverty prevent many people from being able to afford the food which our economic system produces more efficiently and at greater quantities than it ever has.

If 2022 has shown us anything, it is that as long as fossil fuels remain wildly profitable, their production will continue.
Even supposed green asset managers like BlackRock retreat from their bold proposals to sever their ties with the fossil fuel industry.
This just confirms the fact that, as with our broken food system, the market cannot be trusted to distribute goods in a rational, let alone just, way.

Solving climate change would require taking social control over investment — through public ownership and/or worker control — to unleash society’s technological capacities toward decarbonization.
In advancing this project, the legions of predominately working-class humans living in slums or working in factories are not an obstacle but an asset.

item.title: What to Do When the World Is Ending
item.description:
#article #world
tags: #article #world
related:
source: https://medium.com/@YotamMarom/what-to-do-when-the-world-is-ending-99eea2e1e2e7

Answer: Face our despair and choose action e.g. building movements.
Why?: Because we don't know how it will end and what else is possible.

Ok. It’s time to move on. It’s ok to be sad, it’s ok to be angry. But this happens to many people, this and much worse. You’re special, but not that special. Eventually you have to accept this and adjust.
In this case, "this" is referred to loosing a baby, but it can be thought of any (really) bad event.

the experience of the world ending is not new
E.g. due to a prophecy or a real threat, many ancestors also experienced "the end of the world"-feeling. In many cases their worlds did end e.g. the arrival of Columbus or the destruction of Hiroshima. So history is not very positive. But their also is an interesting question: What do people do when their worlds are ending?
In these moments a lot of people do very brave things. Now another questions arises: Why bother if the world was going to end anyway?


Actions are remembered: To inspire other people.
Meaning: e.g. to meet with another human again, fight for a "greater" future I can let the newspapers tell me how my life will go, or I can decide for myself.
George Lakey

People have always been good at imagining the end of the world, which is much easier to picture than the strange sidelong paths of change in a world without end.
Rebecca Solnit writes in Hope in the Dark
Despair is the easy way out. Imagining and fighting for a change in our world is harder. Despair is a self-fulfilling prophecy. We want to be true, so we don't take action and therefor nothing changes and it e.g. "world is ending" really happens.

Despair is also bad politics. But that doesn't have to stay like that. And how should our tiny human brains know, how everything will happen?

Instead of thinking, we already know how it will end, we should take action:

join powerful social movements
build institutions that provide masses of people with a vehicle for belonging, meaning, and long-term struggle.
being authentically alive on this planet in a time of collapse
This requires
good strategy, healthy groups able to wield it, and a movement with a culture open and creative and compelling enough to win over the enormous numbers of people necessary for real transformation.
humility — about what’s possible, about ourselves, about each other. Wherever human beings are, we at least have a chance because we’re not only disasters; we’re also miracles.
James Baldwin
item.guid: media/articles/What to Do When the World Is Ending.md

item.description:

tags: #article #climatecrisis
related:
source: https://www.republik.ch/2023/01/16/wir-haben-kein-recht-vor-der-klimakrise-zu-kapitulieren

Humans fighting against floods and fire, cannot afford it, to lose hope. So why should we do it?
We have the duty, to act in solidarity.
That starts with realising, that the future is not decided yet, because we decide it now.

They and some more have something in common: They pretend to already know, what will happen. But this false certainty apologises doing nothing.
And doing nothing is a luxury. Those in danger cannot do it.
It's a difference if you say "You could get destroyed" or "You will get destroyed": One leaves room for action, the other does not. For those already having an easy life, means giving up, less work (at least concerning own actions at the moment). But for direct affected ones, it means to give up in front of destruction. Giving up becomes the opposite of solidarity.
We don't drown, we fight.
Pacific climate warriors, living on islands dangeroud by rising sea levels

Their attitude over our inseparability of the natural world and our responsibility have changed the moral sense of a lot of people. Indigenous people are worldwide leading in climate protection and conserving their land. A study in 2021 show, that their stopped or delayed at minimum a quarter of the yearly green house gas emission in USA and Canada.

If you don't follow events over decades or centures, you could believe that it comes from the powerful. But it happens on the streets, where it grows until the people in power are forced to approve it.
If we acknowledge, that we don't know the future and the opening is still not clear, then that can get us to shape the future ourselves.

item.title: Wir leben im Verdrängungstheater
item.description:
#article #psychology #theater #climatecrisis #german
tags: #article #psychology #theater #climatecrisis #german
related:
source: https://www.wortblockade.de/wir-leben-im-verdraengungstheater

Vom „Klimakanzler“ bis zur Klimabewegung: fast alle beteiligen wir uns daran, ein Verdrängungstheater aufzuführen. Gemeinsam trudeln wir dem Abgrund entgegen. Das einzige, was hilft: das Theater zu erkennen und zu handeln. Wie kann das gelingen?

Die Letzte Generation bezieht sich auf die Wissenschaft und spricht angesichts drohender Kippunkte von 2-3 Jahren, die uns bleiben, um die schlimmsten Auswirkungen der Klimakrise einzudämmen. Die Mitglieder des Bundestags betonen, jedwede Protestaktion müsse selbstverständlich legal sein. Die naheliegende Rückfrage lautet: trauen Sie dem normalen Parlamentarismus zu, in 2-3 Jahren die Kehrtwende einzuläuten? Nie im Leben würden sie dies behaupten! Aber die Frage wird eben nicht gestellt - bzw. nicht beantwortet. Der Held der parlamentarischen Debatte tritt auf, spricht gewaltige Sätze, tritt wieder ab. Das wars. Die nächste, bitte. „Geduld!“ wird gefordert, besonders von Jüngeren. Klingt irgendwie weise. Ist der Physik aber schnuppe.

Als Meister des Effekts 2022 in der Kategorie Privatperson küre ich indessen einen Zuhörer meines Vortrags zur Klimakrise. Am Ende maulte er: „Ich bin jetzt schon ein wenig enttäuscht. Ich dachte, Sie sagen uns, was man selbst gegen die Klimakrise tun kann!“ Also sage ich (erneut): vorrangig ist die politische Aktion gefragt. „Kommen Sie zur Groß-Demo am Samstag. Nehmen Sie an der Wortblockade teil und schreiben Sie an den Bundeskanzler. Sie können auf Fleisch, aufs Fliegen und aufs Autofahren verzichten, das wäre wichtig.“ Seine Antwort: „Auf Demos gehe ich nicht, das ist nicht so mein Ding. An Olaf Scholz schreibe ich nicht. Fleisch essen, Autofahren und fliegen – mache ich alles weiter.“ Und dann noch: „Das ändert doch nichts, wenn ich das nicht mehr mache.“ Meine Entgegnung: „Wenn Sie jetzt aufstehen und sagen, okay, ich verzichte auf Fleisch, Fliegen, Autofahren, dann wird das hier im Saal alle enorm beeindrucken. Sie werden es weiter erzählen, es wird sich herumsprechen. Ich werde es veröffentlichen!“ Aber das hat nichts verändert. ER WILL NICHT.
