item.title: When McKinsey Comes to Town
item.description:
#remarkN #remarkN #stillToSummarize
#remarkN personal goal/Why?:
#remarkN Most important takeaway:
#stillToSummarize

You’ve probably heard the name “McKinsey.” It usually appears in connection with Fortune 500 companies like General Electric, Microsoft, and Ford. In fact, it’s safe to say almost every major corporation has worked with the consulting powerhouse at some point. 
McKinsey & Company has advised pharmaceutical giants, government regulators, airlines, universities, weapons makers, and media outlets. It’s even counseled US presidential administrations – including those of Obama and Trump.
Operating in 65 countries, McKinsey works with top business, political, and military leaders. Sometimes entire nations hire them for advice. This has netted the firm an estimated worth of $31.5 billion. 
But what does McKinsey actually do to earn these hefty fees?
The company claims to help clients craft innovative policies and strategies to stay competitive. In the grand scheme, it promises to boost economies and make the world a better place. But in reality, its formula for success tends to be quite reductive.
McKinsey’s typical playbook involves slashing costs, laying off workers, and cutting “unnecessary” safety measures. The results are often disastrous, especially for the workers. But even its elite clients sometimes find themselves worse off than before. 
Let’s look at the example of the US Steel Corporation. Once the world’s most profitable steel company, by 2014 it was struggling – failing to keep up with innovation in the industry. The new CEO hired McKinsey to turn things around. As usual, McKinsey laid off dozens of workers. At first, stock prices rose. But by 2015, losses hit $75 million. Even worse, McKinsey made dangerous staff and maintenance cuts despite workers’ protests. Soon, two workers were electrocuted in accidents tied directly to the reductions.
At protests following the deaths, angry workers began chanting “McKinsey sucks!” But in the end, it was US Steel who paid a meager $14,500 in reparations; McKinsey consultants faced no consequences.
The same cycle repeated itself at Disneyland. McKinsey pushed major maintenance cuts to boost profits despite employee warnings about ride safety. Soon, accidents followed – including two tragic deaths. But again, McKinsey denied all responsibility.
This disturbing pattern reveals how McKinsey operates behind its prestigious image. It recommends harsh, cost-cutting measures to satisfy corporate interests. For McKinsey, this is just business. But for ordinary people, it can spell disaster and despair.

Now that we know what McKinsey actually does – versus what it claims to be doing – let’s answer another fundamental question: Who are the people working for McKinsey? 
Most of McKinsey’s consultants are top prospects from elite business schools like Harvard and Stanford. Every year, over 200,000 applicants make a bid to join the prestigious firm – but McKinsey only accepts around 1 or 2 percent. Like many consulting firms, McKinsey sells ambitious graduates on wealth, prestige, and solving complex problems. But it also promises the chance to positively impact the world. 
The company appeals to idealistic recruits who want purpose along with a paycheck. But recent media exposés have revealed a huge gap between McKinsey's supposed values and the shady reality of its operations. 
Because McKinsey barely discloses its work, many young consultants learn about the firm’s dealings with corrupt governments and deeply unethical corporations only after they join. For instance, it was revealed McKinsey paid $600 million to settle probes into its role exacerbating the opioid crisis – but more on that later. 
McKinsey's ethos of profits over people was baked in from the start. When hired by GM in the 1950s to study executive pay, the consultants found that wages were rising faster for workers than CEOs. The elite were outraged, so McKinsey swooped in to “help.”
It provided fashionable cost-cutting advice to reverse the trend, actively working against workers’ interests. By the 1980s, McKinsey openly advocated for layoffs as “increased efficiency,” gutting payrolls to pump up stock prices. Offshoring was touted as benefiting consumers despite harming workers. Unions declined as jobs moved south, then overseas. Even amid skyrocketing wealth inequality, McKinsey recommended higher CEO compensation.
The consultants did their job well. In 1950, CEOs made 20 times the amount that average workers did. By 2020, it was 351 times as much. McKinsey's role as capitalism's cutthroat cheerleader made some uneasy given its lofty principles. But for McKinsey, huge corporate profits eclipse any hypocrisy.
Theoretically, McKinsey lets its consultants refuse unethical projects. But in practice, saying no to big clients can be a death sentence for the consultants’ careers.

McKinsey doesn't just advise corporations – it also works extensively for the US government. This includes frequent consulting on health-care and immigration policies. But if you think it adjusts its profit-first approach for governmental work, you’re sorely mistaken. 
For instance, McKinsey was a main architect of Medicaid’s implementation, often securing contracts through insider connections. In Illinois, it used its ties to initially consult pro bono, but eventually secured $75 million in state deals. Later, investigations struggled to understand what McKinsey’s costly work actually consisted of. Meanwhile, the state hospitals of Illinois remained direly underfunded, with many struggling to provide basic services. 
Similar patterns occurred in Arkansas and Missouri, with early free advice opening the floodgates to precious state contracts. Nationally, McKinsey has received over $1 billion in federal contracts, typically without competitive bidding. 
For instance, McKinsey regularly consults for the FDA – the Federal Drug Administration. At the same time, it works for the drug companies the FDA regulates. McKinsey has even hired former FDA officials to help its Big Pharma clients speed up drug approvals and avoid problems with the regulating body.
Beyond health care, McKinsey has also faced outrage for extensive work helping US Immigrations and Customs Enforcement (ICE) implement harsh Trump immigration policies. The firm played a role in expediting deportations as well as advocating for cost-cutting measures that risked creating humanitarian crises.
For instance, the company argued that ICE's food standards at their detention centers were “too high” and should be drastically lowered. When confronted by some of their own consultants, management defended the work as professional problem-solving, detached from politics. 
These examples illustrate the huge gap between McKinsey's squeaky-clean image and controversial government work. In each case, its opaque culture has enabled the company to deny responsibility and downplay clear conflicts of interest.

McKinsey hasn't just undermined public health services – it has also actively contributed to harming public health by working with irresponsible industries.
In the 1950s, McKinsey began working with tobacco company Philip Morris, providing manufacturing and research advice. 
After the 1964 Surgeon General report confirmed smoking's links to cancer, there was no doubt McKinsey knew about the many harms of smoking. Yet it kept working with the tobacco industry, recommending ways for Philip Morris to keep profits up through targeted marketing. As public sentiment turned against Big Tobacco, McKinsey even took on more industry clients like RJ Reynolds and Lorillard.
It devised sales pitches aimed specifically at teens and minorities. In addition, McKinsey assisted “Project Cerberus,” a secret plan by three tobacco giants to defeat global anti-smoking efforts.
When e-cigarettes appeared, McKinsey jumped on the new trend. It started consulting for vaping startup Juul, using its ties to get the product past the FDA. 
But it gets worse. In the early 2000s, McKinsey began advising Purdue Pharma, maker of OxyContin, a powerful and highly addictive opioid painkiller. McKinsey helped Purdue counter critics and reformulate OxyContin to sustain sales amid rising addiction levels.
By 2013, with declining sales, McKinsey pushed radical ideas to “turbocharge” Purdue's engine. It suggested focusing on areas like Fort Wayne, where opioid overdoses were already surging. It also proposed countering pharmacies that were trying to curb access by creating alternative opioid distribution channels. 
In sum, the consultants did all they could to contribute to the ongoing opioid crisis – the most deadly drug epidemic in US history.
In the cases of tobacco and opioids, McKinsey worked both sides, advising the companies while also consulting for the FDA office on how to regulate the drugs. And both times, the conflict of interest was hidden for years.
In 2021, McKinsey paid $600 million to settle claims it fueled the opioid crisis, while still denying legal wrongdoing. But whether unlawful or not, McKinsey has repeatedly and knowingly aided companies peddling dangerous products. Nowhere is the firm's hypocrisy more glaring than in its work for industries that prey on vulnerable populations despite the deadly costs.

McKinsey doesn’t just meddle in politics – it also disrupts the financial sector. 
The firm has longstanding ties to Wall Street, advising top finance leaders since the 1930s. Many former McKinsey consultants have ended up working for questionable finance firms like Goldman Sachs, and vice versa. 
These deep ties helped McKinsey play an important but rarely discussed role in the 2008 financial crisis. 
Decades before, McKinsey had counseled banks on restructuring their finance policies to increase risk and returns. In the 1980s, it began aggressively promoting a strategy called “securitization,” which bundles multiple loans into tradable securities.
Consultants touted securitization as a superior technology that was more efficient and safer than traditional lending. In reality, securitization is extremely risky. It fueled excessive speculation while simultaneously muddying transparency and ensuring a widespread domino effect of problems. 
Nonetheless, McKinsey published how-to guides and articles on the concept, encouraging banks worldwide to adopt it. Energy giant Enron radically implemented McKinsey’s securitization strategy before its epic collapse in the early 2000s. But few people cared or understood what was going on.
By 2007, McKinsey veterans occupied top posts at Lehman Brothers, Morgan Stanley, and UBS. Their process of securitization had enabled subprime mortgages to be bundled, rated deceptively high, and sold globally. 
The system soon imploded, sparking the 2008 financial crisis – the worst since the Great Depression. For Wall Street bankers, it was a game with minimal consequences. But millions of ordinary Americans never recovered, facing joblessness and foreclosure.
Once more, McKinsey escaped accountability, claiming the crisis involved instruments different from the early securitizations it promoted. But the truth is, it normalized reckless practices that fueled disaster. 

No matter where you go in the world, McKinsey’s impact is hard to escape.
A fresh wave of controversy hit the firm in 2018, when its dealings with corrupt firms and unstable government institutions in South Africa came to light.
After apartheid ended in 1994, the nation’s hopes for empowering Black South Africans quickly gave way to a wave of corruption. McKinsey entered the scene in 2005, advising state rail and port agency Transnet. 
By 2015, it had a $700 million contract to restructure state power utility Eskom. But amid corrupt officials and dubious contracts, the firm soon proved to be in over its head. 
To work in South Africa, McKinsey needed local Black-owned partner companies, but it repeatedly failed to vet these firms. Its first big partner, Regiments Capital, was linked to the Gupta family, which was accused of using connections to “capture” South African agencies and loot public funds. McKinsey dumped Regiments in 2016 and chose Trillian as a new partner – again without vetting. Trillian wasn’t even Black-owned. It also had clear conflicts of interest. In one case, it advised power company Eskom on the purchase of a new boiler – while also advising the Chinese seller of said boiler. 
Facing scrutiny, McKinsey returned $74 million in fees from the improper deals. But the damage was done. Eskom was left with financial and operational troubles, leading to massive blackouts. To this day, South Africans still spend multiple hours without electricity on a regular basis. 
This wasn't an isolated incident of McKinsey enabling greed and corruption. Since the 1970s oil boom, the firm has had longstanding ties to Saudi Arabia's repressive regime. By 2016, McKinsey had 137 active Saudi projects, advising government agencies and state oil firm Aramco.
In 2011, as Arab Spring revolutions swept the region, McKinsey worked with the royal family to quell unrest. It suggested implementing symbolic reforms like allowing women to drive, while upping repression of dissent. These strategies were then introduced by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who oversaw the Saudi war in Yemen and was implicated in the 2018 killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi – among many other human rights abuses. 
McKinsey has also expanded its work with Chinese government and state firms despite similar human rights criticisms. In 2018, the firm even held a lavish company retreat there, meters away from detention camps for the oppressed Uyghur Muslim minority.
Time and again, McKinsey has demonstrated its willingness to work with authoritarian regimes and support their antidemocratic agendas. It claims to improve the countries it works with. But its actions frequently empower corruption, graft, and oppression.

One of McKinsey’s oft-touted values is sustainability. At forums like Davos, its consultants issue urgent warnings about climate change and emphasize their commitment to “protecting the planet.”
But in reality, McKinsey works extensively for major oil, gas, and coal companies worldwide – including top carbon emitters like ExxonMobil, Chevron, and Teck Resources. In China, McKinsey advised major steelmakers hungry for coking coal from Teck. In Indonesia, the world's second-largest coal exporter, McKinsey has counted two big coal miners as clients. As usual, McKinsey helps these companies cut costs, boost efficiency, and increase production.
The personal story of a former consultant illustrates the hypocrisy at play. As a young recruit, Erik Edstrom joined McKinsey in the hopes of working on projects related to sustainability. But once on the job, he found hardly any of these projects. Instead, there were abundant opportunities advising coal companies. 
One day, Edstrom even received a peppy video titled “Turning a Coal Mine into a Diamond in 6 Months.” It was a motivational video about how McKinsey had helped a client increase coal production by 26 percent. 
Despite coal's major contribution to carbon emissions, McKinsey partners celebrated the project as a big success. When Edstrom refused to work for fossil fuel clients, he found his career stalled. Today, he believes McKinsey’s opt-out policy is a way to avoid taking a clear stance on critical issues.
Recently, junior consultants protested McKinsey's hypocrisy in a letter signed by over 1,100 employees. But leaders defended working with polluters, explaining that “Companies can’t go from brown to green without getting a little dirty.”
The firm's climate rhetoric aims to have it both ways – sounding progressive on sustainability while guiding big polluters on wringing every last million from planet Earth. This allows McKinsey to keep climate-concerned young recruits in the pipeline without altering its actual work.
As of 2020, McKinsey still has no major green energy clients. Instead, it keeps reaping hundreds of millions in fees advising Big Oil and Gas.
It's hard to imagine the full extent of damage McKinsey is doing with its work behind the veil of confidentiality. Without transparency and accountability, McKinsey's pattern of calamitous advice seems poised to continue – human consequences be damned. 

Behind its polished image, McKinsey & Company fuels inequality, corruption, and crises worldwide. The prestigious firm earns billions advising corporations, governments, and despots, while its veil of secrecy allows it to deny accountability.
Through ruthless cost-cutting and questionable policies, McKinsey's profit motive has wreaked havoc across innumerable sectors – including public health, immigration, the environment, and the global economy. Its partners deflect blame while advancing harmful agendas that make the world more unstable. 
Time and time again, McKinsey has proven its own values as hollow – betraying people to serve privileged elites. Without transparency, it’s hard to imagine the firm will change the way it operates.

item.title: When You're Ready, This Is How You Heal
item.description:
#remarkN #remarkN #stillToSummarize
#remarkN personal goal/Why?: How to overcome and process past events properly, so they don't affect myself (anymore).
#remarkN Most important takeaway
#stillToSummarize

Struggling to stay in the comfort of the familiar, we often don blinders, ignoring the paths opening before us. Put yourself in the shoes of a hiker. You might've set off on a path, content with the route you’ve chosen. But if you're constantly glancing at the map, doubting your direction, you're likely on the wrong trail. It's when you're embracing the journey, absorbing the beauty around you, that you're on the right path.
Life isn't about following a rigid script – hitting milestones doesn't necessarily equate to fulfillment. It’s almost like following a recipe to the letter, yet the finished dish is tasteless. Fulfillment doesn't come from checking boxes but from being in tune with your soul, exploring, growing, and adapting.
Now, you might ask, What if I feel like I'm falling behind? Well, imagine you're in a race, but instead of a flat track, it’s a maze. Everyone takes different turns, some reach dead-ends, some find shortcuts. There’s no single way to reach the end, no timeline to adhere to. Feeling like you're falling behind is an illusion because life isn't about reaching checkpoints at a prescribed time but about the journey itself.
So, what can you do to embrace change? First, instead of measuring your life against others, tune into your own rhythm. It's like dancing – when you're too focused on matching others' steps, you lose the joy of the dance. Instead, focus on how the music moves within you.
Second, recognize that setbacks aren’t failures but opportunities for redirection and growth. Remember the hiking example? A blocked trail isn't a setback – it's an invitation to discover a path you may not have considered, a chance to witness new vistas and wonders.
So when life offers you an opportunity to change, take it. Trust the process and give yourself the chance to get it right. Remember, the real journey is the one that resonates with the deepest part of you, the one that allows your soul to express its truth fully. It’s in embracing change and exploring the different paths that you’ll truly bring your inner world into the world around you.

But what if you could view letting go in a different light? The truth is that it's not a single momentous event, but a practice, a skill to be honed. Just as you’d train for a marathon by first running shorter distances, you can learn to let go by starting with the smaller things. This could mean releasing a passing thought, or deciding not to engage in an insignificant argument. It might involve parting with objects that merely remind you of a bygone era or releasing the expectations you place on others to live according to your narratives.
Consider the clothes that no longer fit your evolving identity. You're not the same person you were when you bought that favorite shirt years ago. By holding on to these articles, you're clinging to a version of yourself that you've outgrown. Letting go of these physical items can be symbolic of the more significant emotional and psychological changes that are occurring within you.
Extend this idea to the people in your life. Some of these individuals may not be ready to reciprocate the love you extend. Investing love in those who aren't prepared to reciprocate is like watering a plant that's unwilling to grow – you're wasting precious resources that could be nurturing flowers ready to bloom. The first step here is to identify these relationships, reevaluate them, and determine where you should be focusing your energy. Remember, you're not really letting go, you're accepting what's already gone. Herein lies the heart of the matter – what you invest your energy in defines your existence.
This leads to another nugget of wisdom – to make it a priority to cultivate a space filled with individuals who genuinely care, listen, and connect. Imagine this as a garden. The more you water the plants that are eager to grow, the more you'll see your garden flourish. The same concept applies to relationships – the more energy you pour into genuine connections, the more rewarding they become.
As you practice the art of letting go and embrace your worthiness, you create room for what truly nourishes your soul. You step into the fullness of your life, ready to embrace all that is ready to love you back.
(People, that don't love you) You just let people go, that aren' there anymore.

That's what we, as fellow human beings, are searching for: stories that mirror our own, works that meet us where we are, creations that make us feel understood and seen. The most potent way to create this connection is to bare a piece of your soul, to translate your unique essence onto the canvas of your craft. That's what matters. That's what resonates.

In the journey of life, there's a chance that you've veered off course, letting societal expectations and opinions override your instincts. This deviation isn't your fault, rather it's a consequence of conditioning that started when you were young. Remember the kid who fearlessly wore clothes that made them smile, acted on ideas without second thoughts, or expressed hunger without guilt? Gradually, societal norms and expectations robbed you of that innate sense of self. You began to doubt your reflection in the mirror, base your clothing choices on hiding your perceived flaws, and question your hunger cues. This disconnect from your own instincts creates a sense of self-doubt, breeding a cycle of overcorrection and self-sabotage.
Overcorrection is the equivalent of aiming to fix what's not broken, assuming that every aspect of your life is fundamentally flawed. This might mean pushing yourself to the limits of productivity, trying to fit into an idealized image, or obsessing over the outward appearance of social connections. This vicious cycle of overcorrection is birthed from the feeling of not being good enough and from a relentless quest for external validation.
So, how can you break free from this relentless cycle of overcorrection?
Start by reconnecting with your honest opinions. It's as simple as trying new food, listening to a new playlist, or watching a new movie. This process of engaging with your genuine opinions will gradually restore your instincts.
Next, tune in to your basic needs: hunger, thirst, tiredness. Take note of them and respond accordingly. This will reestablish your connection with your most fundamental instincts.
Remember, overcorrection is a learned behavior, much like your reaction to others. By granting others your approval and appreciating them for who they are, you gradually raise the bar for self-acceptance and decrease the competitive mentality around worthiness and connection.
Lastly, stop taking everything personally. People's judgments are often projections of their own issues, not a verdict on your worth. When you grasp this concept, the origin of your problems shifts from a personal attack to collateral damage from someone else's wounds.
Listen to the quiet voice within you. If there’s an aspect of your life that genuinely needs change, you'll know. But the motivation for change should come from a place of self-respect, not external validation.
The magic unfolds when you accept yourself exactly as you are. Only then can you transform into everything you possibly could be. Releasing judgment and determining your personal “enough” is a crucial step in reclaiming your life.

item.title: Your future self
item.description:
#book #author #future #self #selfimprovement #remarkN
#book Your future self
#author nameOfAuthor
tags: #future #self #selfimprovement
related:
key to good decision-making is a clear and empathetic understanding of your future self

Take a moment to reflect on the tale of Pedro Rodrigues Filho, a man born into brutality, bearing a dented skull from his father's beatings. Rodrigues Filho, who died in 2023, was a serial killer who had murdered 71 people by 1985. Yet his story didn't end in a prison cell. He started working out, learned to read and write, and in 2007, thanks to a legal loophole, walked out of prison a free man. He began waking up at 4 a.m. daily, abstained from drugs and alcohol, shared inspirational stories on YouTube, and counseled young criminals, swearing that he was repulsed by his former self and considering himself reborn.
So can we change ourselves fundamentally?


Our perception of our future selves profoundly influences our current decisions
think of our future self as an extension of your present self or even a good friend (not as a stranger)
then we are more likely to make good decisions (than we would for a stranger)
A day in the present feels longer than the anticipation of a day spent on a task six months from now.
If we don't actively focus on our future selves, we risk making decisions in the present that could lead to future regret. So perhaps it's time to weigh anchor and let our future selves guide us as we navigate the sea of choices that life presents.
interesting: more patience, when immediacy of present is removed
options: $1000 in six months or $990 right now => most choose $990 now
options: $900 in a year or $1000 in eighteen months => most people choose $1000


compose a letter or time capsule to make future self more tangible
visualise your future, and then mentally travel back to the present => take concrete steps
contemplating the future, use days instead of years as your unit of time – a perspective that's easier to comprehend and operationalise

We struggle to imagine our future selves vividly, therefor we make bad decisions and:

procrastinate
say yes, but then damn: have you ever agreed to something scheduled for a future time, only to regret it when that time came


projection bias – our tendency to assume our future selves will feel the way we currently do
end-of-history-illusion – our belief that our personality and preferences won't change much in the future


instant punishments ( #remarkN that sounds a little too harsh and I'm not a fan of punishments anyways :) )
make present more enoyable
e.g. connect nice things to otherwise unappealing tasks
break down difficult goals

item.title: Good habits to establish
item.description:
#book #author #habits #psychology #video
#book 12 Rules for Life - An antidote to chaos
#author Jordan B. Peterson
tags: #habits #psychology
overview:


A fixed sleep schedule and a good breakfast is very important. This can already solve a lot of mental ilnesses.
I think it is in general about having a schedule and structure in daily life.

Standing straight, shoulders back makes you feel more confident. Look forward (not down) and walk tall.

Smiling also makes happier and so healthier.

Express your desires and opinion. Just then you can get positive feedback and others know how you feel. More likely good things will happen.
And if you get "bad" feedback, you can learn from it. But I think most often people are in 1 on 1 situations nice and rather want to please. That can be bad also, if you don't get critical feedback at all.

Often we treat ourselves worse than we treat our family or strangers. We have far higher expectations and punish ourselves (at least with thoughts) far more often.
A little similar to "Just do to others, what you would like to be done to you, too.".


What you aim at determines what you see. Your attitude has a big impact on the result.
An example with eyes: They can focus just on some few things, others are peripheral with low resolution. So use every tool wisely and now what to "look for".
#video Basketball Awareness Test with bear walking through

Don't define "better" because totalitarianism is bad. It should and will change over time and manifest in different actions.

Ask

What bothers me?
Could I fix (a part of) it?
Would I fix (a part of) it?
What are you waiting for, do it!

Step by step and day by day improve yourself.
Then you are less concerned about others (actions) because you know you have enough to do for yourself.
Compare yourself to who you were yesterday. (And not to others)

If you always say yes (also to little things you dislike), you cannot say no at a moment when it matters the most.

A new information can destroy old beliefs and challenge us before it is reborn as something better. Every bit of learning is a little death.
Assume that the poerson you are listening to knows something you don't.

memory is a tool to prevent negative events happening again in the future. To learn from the past.

Improve listening and undestanding of others.
After sb. spoke try to summarize it and ask if that's right. If not improve until the other person aggrees on it.

In a crisis just think about it in scheduled time, so you don't get overwhelmed.
With that you can also preserve energy. Crisis is not one battle, it's a long lasting war.
Schedule the time during the day, not before sleeping (otherwise you cannot sleep well).

Pet a cat when there is one on the street as an example. And strive for improving everything around you by improving yourself :)


In an unstable world, short-term success is desirable. Because you don't know if the situation chances at once, so you rather take whatever you can if possible.
In comparison in a stable world long-term thinking is better.

Shame is natural and comes with self-consciousness. The ideal (e.g. person with the perfect body) shames everyone else. But also death shames the living.
Nudity is especially shameful because then one is very vulnerable and everyone can see ones short comings.

is not doubtable.

Each human being has an immense capacity of evil.
Worst sin: Torment of others for the sake of it. And the good is whatever strive to stop it/such things.
BUT if there is something not good, there has to be good things, too.


Aim high, pay attention
fix what you can fix
Don't be arrogant in your knowledge
Become aware of your own insufficiency e.g. malevolence
Say the truth or at least don't lie!
To the best of my ability I will act in a manner that leads to the alleviation of unnecessary pain and suffering.

When something bad happens (e.g. our car breaks down or our partner is not honest) we not only are confronted with chaos, but we also question ourselves.
Chaos grows over time until it breaks out tremendously. So we have to try to fix it at any time and don't ignore even the little things.



Say only those things that make you strong.
Start to stop doing what you know to be wrong.
Fix what you can and the rest will be bearable.

If you are disciplined and privilege the future over the present you can change the structure of reality.



for their discipline.
and your own boundaries/limits. So you don't react badly, because of something else.



Men loose when competing against women anyways because

if they win, it's clear/they should have won and maybe lose in status because the have beaten a woman and are too dominant.
if they lose it's a shame
So they can only really compete against men to "win".

Collective pursuit always produces winners and losers.
The pursuit of goals is one measuring of life. That creates hierarchy. Otherwise, if there would be always the same outcome for everybody, it is not worth pursuing.

item.title: content
item.description:
#about #terms

#about climate change/crisis and adapting nature: What does it mean for our lives? For sure nature will change, but how!?
author: Bernhard Kegel



climate change is caused by humans with a probability higher than 95%
about 890 billion ton of CO2 equivalent was emmitted in the last 3 decades by humans
In one generation happens, what normally happens in 10'000 years
- (my thought) Would be good if we live longer, so we would care more about the future and think about our steps, before we take them... The fairy tale of the slow emerging climate crisis could be as damaging as saying climate heating doesn't exist.
- David Wallace-Well


since Industrialization CO2 parts per million from 280 to 400 ppm
The main reaction to changing environment/temperature is moving/changing the habitat and it is essential to interchange between population (e.g. genes, distribution of seeds and nutrition)
but today 50-70% of the continent are changed more or less by humans and a big part has no natural vegetation any more => so most of the wild animals cannot move freely but are rather in a prison
animals widen their habitat to the colder regions, on cost of the animals living there...
ocean temperature changes less than continent temperature, but fish still have to travel more bc. temperature gradient is more flat (a bigger part/area changes)


core problem: What part of an event or development is caused by climate change?
=> Everything is moving, and nature will be a composition of new and old creatures, where the new one will probably dominate more as temperatures rise.

#terms Neozoen Neophyten Neobiota Neomyceten

often invasive species, which were not intended to be released in a new region but rather hold prison e.g. as a "pet", cause problems
- Of course not animals or plants are the problem, but only humans which caused the displacement.
- Problems: new species could extinguish domiciled species
- especially in poor countries where they have no/less money and know-how to combat Neobiota
- e.g. in germany 400 of 4000 plants are Neophytes, in urban areas it is even 40-50% of all plants (because these are the centres where introduced species mostly arrive)
- through climate warming species will spread and also settle in non-human areas
- Since 1993 there is an agreement for combating Neobiota but just half of the countries are doing something, even though the economic and agricutlurel damages could be really big
=> As long as climate changes (rapidly) flora and fauna will, too and we know little to none about it and its impacts... Especially because all forecasts last to 2050 or maximal to 2100...


often scientists know the unknows, dangerous are the unknown unknowns
we know/can reconstruct the global temperature since 550 million years through proxies (records are as young as 300 years)
current geological status
poles are covered with ice (last time was 300 million years ago)
cenozoic glacial epoch: short warum periods with more cold periods
in comparison to ("normally on earth")
far warmer than today

#author Umberto Eco



Es gibt einen Unterschied zwischen realen Verschörungen und leeren Verschwörungen. Reale Verschörungen werden "aufgedeckt", ob sie erfolgreich sind oder nicht z.B. der Sturz Caesars oder das Orsini-Komplott zur Ermordung Napoleons des 3. Bei leeren Verschwörungen ist es wie bei Geheimnissen: Je leerer desto mächtiger und verlockender, da es weder widerlegt noch erwiesen werden kann.
Früher hat mensch Göttern nachgesagt, die Welt zu "kontrollieren"/für die Geschehen verantwortlich zu sein. Heute sind es mächtige/reiche Menschen und Gruppen, die (meist) für das (böser) verantwortlich gemacht werden.
"Die Bevölkerung" sucht nach Erklärungen für Entscheidungen von "Mächtigen/Reichen" und da einige Dinge geheim gehalten werden, werden andere "Fakten" zusammengewürfelt und eine Verschwörungstheorie entsteht.
Leere Verschwörungen sind gefährlich, da sie neue Probleme schaffen (welche ja gar keine sind) und dadurch von den wirklichen Problemen ablenken.

item.title: A panel data study on the effect of climate change on life expectancy
item.description:
#remarkN #remarkN
#remarkN personal goal: Learn about life expectancy.
#remarkN Most important takeaway: Climate change significantly decreases life expectancy, especially for females.

The finding of this study suggests that if the annual average temperature increases by 1°C, then the life expectancy at birth will decline by 0.44 years. Moreover, the temperature rise will further negatively impact life expectancy by interacting with the rainfall cycle. If the composite climate change index, an index of the geometric mean of temperature and rainfall, increases by 10 points, the life expectancy at birth will decline by 0.50 years. Moreover, climate change will disproportionately reduce the life expectancy of females more than the life expectancy of males.
item.guid: media/studies/A panel data study on the effect of climate change on life expectancy.md

item.title: 5 Ways People Try to Help Someone With ADHD That Aren’t Actually Helpful (and What to Do Instead)
item.description:
#remarkN #remarkN #remarkN
#remarkN personal goal/Why?: Improve how I can help people with ADHD
#remarkN Most important takeaway

clean for them => clean with them so everybody know where things are now
make tags to describe what's where
also people with ADHD have a system, even though it might not be that obvious ( #remarkN it's not that obvious sometimes with any people^^)
do a task first and then take a break => first break or set a specific time
otherwise task just takes a long time and may not be done anyways
break helps a lot
(e.g. when a deadline got missed) saying "it's not urgent" e.g. "do it whenever you want" results probably in not being done at all => ask "until when can you do it?"
suggesting a system that works for you to people with ADHD, sets expectations and probably leads to failure, bc. they may be at another place of progress => ask what system they are currently using and try to suggest (slight) improvement to it
saying "everyone struggles with this" may have good intention to normalise struggles and lower loneliness, but most of the time, people don't struggle with it to the same extent and it can be invalidating => listen and understand the (unique) experience
when everyone struggle with it, is the ADHD person not just he one person who hasn't figured it out? this can lead to more loneliness and shame
same with saying that a task is "easy" => let people find on out on their own how easy it is for them, maybe you can help with the steps
do the hard task first, but that requires a lot of motivation, so if this is not done, nothing gets done => easy tasks first to build a running start
item.guid: media/videos/youtube/5 Ways People Try to Help Someone With ADHD That Aren’t Actually Helpful (and What to Do Instead).md

item.title: 7 comforting phrases that are actually hurtful
item.description:
#video #year #creator
#video 7 comforting phrases that are actually hurtful
#year 2023
#creator Psych2Go

Good attention but bad outcome:
It's okay, you get over it.

Bad: The other person may suppress their feelings and don't process their emotions about it anymore
Better: "You're feelings are valid" to give them space to process it.
There are other people dying./Other people have bigger problems.
Bad: Other may feel bad and don't open up next time.
Better: "What can I do to help you?"
What you have to do is/giving advice
Not necessarily bad, but when they open up to you and you give advice, it's possible that they think, they are not trying hard enough or that they are the problem.
Better: Rather give them space and motivate them to push forward/that they can do it.
You know, I went through the same thing
Bad: Telling one's story avoids to talk about the other people's feelings (takes the light away from them). Can lead to toxic positivity.
Better: try not to make it about yourself
Everything happens for a reason
sometimes it can work, but not when others are at the peak of their emotions. Can lead to thinking, that what the other went through makes sense (but that is not always the case).
can encourage hope, but also excessive positivity
Better: "I wish I had the right words to make sense, but I don't. Nonetheless I'm here to listen."
At least you have a job.
We try to highlight positive things in others life. But that can suppress other feelings then.
Better: "I don't know what to say, but you are very brave for opening up."
It's okay. I know what that feels like.
Bad: Truth is that you don't. Grieve and pain are common emotions, but every person feels them differently.
Better: "I could not imagine what you are going through right now."
item.guid: media/videos/youtube/7 comforting phrases that are actually hurtful.md

#year 2021
#creator BRAINY DOSE

Being messy: promotes creativity and doesn't restrict (as an ordered one may do)
Staying up late
biological reasoning
(in earlier times,) night was(/is) more dangerous thus our ancestors being up/working/defending at night, had to be more intelligent to survive
creative predecessors would stay up all night with varying circadian rythms
more introverted: prefer nighttime with less people to think without interruption
explanation is not workaholism ( #remarkN Maybe, at least today, that could be an own "habit" of "highly intelligent" people^^)
swearing: knowing more cursed words, means having a broader vocabulary ( #remarkN I would definitely challenge than and, if at all, frame it the other way around)
Take cold showers: Examples are Benjamin Franklin would swim in London's Themse river or Theodore Roosevelt went winter skinny-dipping in the Potomac River in Washington, D.C.
improves mental and physical well-being as well as productivity
chewing annoying them bc. unable to block out irrelevant sensory information
Doodle: either bored or smart
helps in memory 8 Things Highly Intelligent People Do Differently with visual expression of thoughts
allows the brain a brake so the mind than subconsciously wander
Criticising themselves: know that they don't know everything
Day dreaming: too much focus can lead to overthinking and missing a (better) solution => brain can later come back with a fresh view
Talking to themselves: e.g. saying names out loud can help to remember and enables visual processing
liking being alone: less is more
evolutionary: hunters and gathers lived in small groups up to 150 people, frequent contact was crucial to survive and reproduce
but with social media and higher stimulation is too much and steals focus
being a coach potato: bc. it allows for more brain activity without using energy on physical tasks ( #remarkN I would at least challenge that or reduce it to small windows, when that happens bc. being active (for some time) has so many good effects besides others on thinking)

item.title: SmartCity
item.description:
#video #year #creator
#video Barcelone, Vorbild für die ganze Welt! So funktioniert die Smart-Citiy | Galileo | ProSieben
#year 2021
#creator Galileo


A lot of sensors, in bins or in laterns, gather data of the environment: Air quality, noise, count of cars and others. Solar hubs, special laterns, were developed which run with solar energy and have a lot of sensors to tell the city and the responsible people, where action has to be taken, where it is more needed.

solar hubs
run with solar energy
measure a lot of things
data is used to evaluate where action is (most) needed
like reducing traffic, changing routes

Buildings were chosen to build a "super block". There the streets were changed from roads for cars to mainly zones for the residents. Just the redient's cars are allowed to drive with 10km/h. All the other traffic was bypassed around this block. The super block makes the citiy and their citizens healthier through noise and air pollution reduction.

cars were changed to pedestrian zones
a lot of plants, banks to sit and playground for kids
places to meet people and hang out for young and old :)
just redisents are allowed to drive with their cars with 10km/h
air pollution and noise reduction

This change was just possible with the expansion of the local public traffic. Otherwise there would be too much individual traffic in the city for the streets.

every citizien which gives up their car, gets 3 years of free local public traffic

Solar cars can be used liked batteries. Because cars stand a lot of the time during the day, then electricity can be used for the houses and its consumption. With the invenvtion of wallbox, an AI/algorithm, electricity can be used where it is needed most. During the day, when the cars stand, it is used in the house. Of course all car shelters have solar panels on the roofs. The algorithm calculates when the car is needed and will charge it/let enough power in it for this duration. At night, when electricity prices are low it will be charded.

cars are used as rolling/standing batteries
AI calculates where energy is needed most at the moment
smart charging

3 trainings are suitable

item.title: How I Study With a Full-Time Job My Strategic Scheduling
item.description:
#disclaimer
#disclaimer (from the creator) Probably very limited use case

Work (paid work, studying, reading, ...) and non-work (relaxing, videos, friends) affect each other directly.


Fixed work/reward
reward after fixed time/work
fixed work/reward ratio
arbitrary work/reward (like in a video game where it's unsure, when your action gets you to the next level)
reward after variable interval
variable ratio

Arbitrary work/reward is more motivating like a video game^^


have buffers around your time blocks => freedom when to start/end with a task
focus on one topic at a time (context switching requires a lot of time)
don't schedule specific tasks
learn and use your body block e.g. when not a morning person, just schedule everything from midday on (so you don't blame yourself, for not doing anything until 12pm, but rather start just then)

Specify what your rewards are e.g. 6 and then throw a dice every time you want to get rewarded.
Creators' rewards are: meditation, stretching, calling a friend, music, journaling, walking.

In past rewards (like scrolling on the phone, watching YT) were high stimulating or even higher stimulating than the work, which was very energy consuming.
Pick rewards that are

complementary to the work you do e.g. high stimulating <=> low stimulating, non-physical <=> physical
low mental stimulating
That has the advantage to keep energy levels high and lower mental stimulation.
item.guid: media/videos/youtube/How I Study With a Full-Time Job My Strategic Scheduling.md

In video games, there are clear goals to reach. In life not so much. But we can try to still get some clarity with e.g.:
Track your progress trough

some self-examination tests
measure how many lectures, texts, ... you already worked on
So you get clarity on what to do and what you've already done.

Tracking progress and getting clarity can be widened to other othere areas of your life.
And if you're not sure about something, ask e.g.

your professor, if you're unsure, if this is the right subject for you
your parents, if you're not sure about a speech you have to give

As already said, in games you have a clear path to e.g. level up.
Though in life most big goals are also high risk like studying for an exam and just having the opportunity once every year to make it. So it's better to break them down into smaller more manageable goals
#example If there is an exam. You can break it down into questions like

Can I understand this concept?
How else can I solve this problem?
What is the scheme behind all of these similar exercises?
What other questions could come up?

What gets rewarded gets repeated.
James Clear, author of Atomic habits

Video games are very good in consitently getting you back.

In real life, we can achieve a similar effect with learning groups with friends or online in learning sessions. There you can also challenge and help each other out.

item.title: How Quantum Computers Break The Internet... Starting Now
item.description:
#video #year #creator
#video How Quantum Computers Break The Internet... Starting Now
#year 2023
#creator Veritasium


already a thread due to Store now, encrypt later
and all know it
already legislation filed to transform to methods, which cannot be encrypted even by quantum computers

Fundamental are the Qubits, which can not just take one state 0 or 1 but both at the same time.
Thus two Qubits can represent 4 states at the same time and therefor e.g. compute parallely.
BUT we can just "read" one of the possible states by random, and all others are lost when "reading" is done.
So it has be done in a clever way and this has just been figured out for some problems, but they are the ones, nearly all encryption relys on.

Encryption, that even Quantum computers shouldn't be able to break as easy is working with vectors in about 1000 dimensions (seems to be hard enough even for the near future). Two people have "good" vectors (easy to navigate in the dimensions). The recipient, with the grid of dimensions, sends two "bad" vectors (very hard to navigate). Then the sender chooses a data point but with some nois (so not exactly the right one).
Now for any attacker, it's very hard to

find the nearest data point to the send message and
navigate to there with the "bad" vectors given
But for the recipient it's very easy to navigate there, because the recipient has the "good" vectors.
item.guid: media/videos/youtube/How Quantum Computers Break The Internet... Starting Now.md

King dropped some honey on the window frame when handed tea and honey. Servants wants to clean it up. But king says, it's just a drop of honey. The drop further went down the frame and fell on the ground outside.
Servant repeatedly asked, if it should get cleaned. But king denied, it's not a big deal.
Ants, flies and more insects come to eat from it. And even a bird follows.
Then a cat comes to get the bird, which the dogs sees and wants to attack the cat as its nemesis.
Afterwards the two owners of the cat and dog follow and defend their animals. The servant asks, if the guards should intervene, but the king still declines.
After it, all the people from the different villages come to help their animal owner. And now it's too late for the guards.
The kingdom is destroyed, due to a drop of honey and the man in power ignoring it.

item.title: Why Don't We Shoot Nuclear Waste Into Space?
item.description:
#video #year #creator
#video # Why Don't We Shoot Nuclear Waste Into Space?
#year 2022
#creator Kurzgesagt - In a Nutshell

nuclear waste level

90% is low: tools, gloves or trash used at a nuclear facility that could be weakly contaminated, with some short lived radioactivity. This stuff is generally safe for normal disposal.
7% is intermediate: mostly materials that have been in close proximity to a reactor core long enough to become dangerously radioactive. With proper handling it is either safely buried or melted down and mixed into glass or concrete and stored deep underground.
3% is high: very dangerouse and hot



too expensive
not enough rockets
direction unclear
target near object e.g. moon just makes a huge mess
if just launched "near", it could come back (orbits are loops, so they come back, to where they started)
deep into space: even more expensive/more rockets, but still not entirely save, maybe it comes back with some radioactive dust
Sun: pretty hard to it, even though the sun has strong gravity, bc. everything is moving in respect/around it (from earth). So it first had to cancel out all the orbital motion, before it could fall in.
It's easier to launch something out of the entire orbital system, than into the sun.
Exploding: Rockets get better yet, in 2021 there were 11 failures out of 146 launches. Worse than Gernobile bc. it could spread through the atmosphere.

Far more radioactive material is released by coal. Rather low level, but also a lot more and handeled less carefully.

Living within 1.6 km of an ash pile increases your cancer risk up to 2000 times over the acceptable limit.

The increase in cancer is even without other tocis chemicals like heavy metasl or CO2 emissions.

item.title: Will night trains replace planes?
item.description:
#video #year #creator #remarkN
#video Will Night Trains Replace Planes?
#year 2023
#creator Into Europe

Night trains came up in the 50s and 60s. But competition through planes were not far away.
Vanished due to

expensive infrastructure
better options with fast trains (and more passengers => more profit), buses, planes
but some lines like in Austria, East Europe or Spain (where they e.g. didn't have to compete against faster trains)
Then Nightjet by ÖBB (Austria) was a winning strategy targeting environmentalists, families and the well-off. On the night trains they offered seats, cabins and beds. Despite accounting for just 2% of the whole ÖBB offer, they accounted for 17% of the profit. Especially cabins, the most expensive option, was very popular. At the moment they are expanding in different countries like French or Italy.
Because of the different tariffs and subsidies systems in different countries, building night train routes in Europe is a nightmare for companies ( #remarkN What does that remind me off? Ah, yes, cantons in Switzerland...).


don't just go as fast as possible but
also provide comfort
Suggestion by video author: call them night hotels instead of night trains


Advantage

less infrastructure
quite fast from A to B
Disadvantage
needs time to board

Were able to compete against planes through speed e.g. ICE in the 70s and due to little loading time
Advantages

low boarding time
can pick up more passenger at multiple points to contribute economically
Disadvantages
need more traveling time
more expensive infrastructure

Long distance passengers care most about traveling time.

item.title: You're Not Slow Become a Speed Learner in 20 Minutes
item.description:
#video #year #creator #remarkN #remarkN #remarkN #example
#video You're Not Slow: Become a Speed Learner in 20 Minutes
#year 2022
#creator Elizabeth Filips

#remarkN For me it is quite similar to Start with why
Why do you want to learn this? With the following questions, you know what to expect after you learned this. What can and cannot you do with it? So you're not disappointed.


Context: What are we talking about?
Importancy:
Why is this important?
How important is this?
Connections & Limitations
What can I do when I learn this?
What can't I do even when I learnt this?
Further knowledge
- Where I can find further knowledge?
- Who are the experts?
#remarkN Related to the note taking technique from Limitless. There you also have a second column, where you should take notes on the broader topic like "How can I use this" and also "Why must I use this?".

It's also really good, if you can connect information to emotions. #remarkN So it is even more important to connect information and ask, where it fits. Thus you touch on more subjects and have a higher chance on finding connection to subjects your are passionate about.

Not taking notes, but building the foundation for the specifics later on.
So also there ask (maybe stupid sounding) questions like

So we are talking about ...?
So you are saying ...?
That means if ... happens than ... is the consequence?


concepts
maybe things, experts don't even say anymore
How far do they get me? e.g. where can('t) I apply them?
What affects my learning here the most?
How fast can I learn it?

Focus deep on the basics progress:

identify a core skill
test the core skill in different contexts
find where i can’t use the core skill (basically the limits)
Strong core basics means better and faster learning later.


Safety net: The logical backbone: Everything relies on this.
Core basics: Significant and Immediate (everything else builds on it)
Admin: hard (for me), less important
Good for you: don't care, unimportant
E.g. if I'm better at conceptualising but not with names and numbers, then first learn concepts and put names and numbers into Admin or even Good for you

Learn things in the order you are interested in, not in the order they aregiven. That way it's easier to learn longer and stay motivated. Due to the basics you still understand everything, even though you maybe don't follow the given way. Otherwise you burn your motiviation and quit quite fast again.
#example In a book go to chapter 9 first, if that is the most intersting one to you and then maybe chapter 2.

item.title: thermal paste or pad
item.description:
Attention: Thermal pads not reusable and cheaper??? https://nabcooling.com/thermal-pad-everything-you-need-to-know/


For that we need to first know why we even need either of them. First there are more and less efficient material for transferring heat. For example air has around 0.026 W/Km at room temperature which is really little. Metals are much more, around 200 times, heat conductive. And thermal paste can have, depending on the used materials (and so dust the cost), between 3-13 W/Km. Metals are much higher and can have hundreds of W/Km.

The problem is the surface. These metal surfaces, even though they look really flat to our eyes, they aren't at all. So there would be some spikes where metal touches each other but most will be air. This is not good for heat transfering as explained in "Why do we even need either of them?", air is much worse at taking heat. So most heat will be forced to go through the little metal intersections and the chip will overheat fast due to too little heat flow.
There is where thermal paste or pads come in. They remove the air with its better heat conductivity

You can easily cut out the wanted thermal pad, buy the exact height you need for the intersection and even reuse them or don't replace it at least. They are cheaper to get. And last but not least easier to use. There won't be a mess with thermal paste on components you didn't want it to be. So why do we even need thermal paste then?

The advantage thermal paste has, is how much you use of it. As we discussed earlier metal has an even better conductivity rate than thermal paste and pads. So if possible you just want to fill the air spaces with past and let metal touch metal wherever possible. Probably not really practical doable... So the best way is to just put as little paste on the chip as possible. That is not possible with the paste. It can not redistribute itself, there will be the same thickness everywhere.

Use thermal paste when you need as much heat transfer/cooling as possible. But be aware that less can be more. When putting the chip on the cooling pad the paste will "flow" where it is need and not take up more space. Just a tiny surface not allowing air in it.
On the other hand thermal pads are better for covering surfaces which have a greater distance between it and its cooling component. It is use for example on VRAMs where it is more important to have a connection (which is still pretty good, but not "perfect") than cooling as much as possible.
